CHAPTER XIV: Concerning the Church

I. The Church: A Holy Society of the Called

Hitherto, we have beheld the benefits of God bestowed upon individual men—those called, justified, and sanctified—and what things they must both believe and do. It followeth that we should also survey them in the holy society, or Church, which is the assembly of the called.

Martyr saith: So great is the dignity of the divine calling that the Church hath thence derived its name from ek and kalein (to call out). Verily, it is naught else but the congregation of those who are called.

Junius saith: The term “ecclesia,” derived from ekkalein, was renowned and oft-used among the Athenians, properly signifying a company summoned from their seats unto a place to hear some matter. Hence, the name was borrowed and translated unto a more sacred use. And certes, it most aptly befitteth the thing it signifieth, for the Church, if thou regardest the force of the word, is nothing other than the assembly of men called forth. For they who pertain unto the true Church are called out from this world—that is, from men who are entangled in worldly affairs—into one body, and as it were, a holy commonwealth. None enter this number save those called by God; none lean upon their own strength, but all who come are forestalled by the calling of God. This Church, moreover, is the gathering of those whom God doth graciously call unto the worship of His glory and the fruit thereof.

Trelcatius saith: For the understanding of the Church, a twofold exposition is altogether needful: one nominal, the other essential. The former doth commonly expound the homonymy of the word; the latter doth singularly set forth the very nature of the Church. The nature of the word itself must be considered and explained in twain ways: etymologically and logically. Etymologically, “ecclesia” denoteth an assembly called by public authority. Logically, “ecclesia” is numbered among those things which logicians call collective and aggregative—that is, such as are not one thing absolutely, but contain within themselves two: the one akin to a multitude and scattered matter, the other to unity, order, and collection. In both ways considered, the Church hath a threefold signification. The first is most general, under which not only angels are comprehended, but also, politically, any civil assembly; and improperly, the false Church, which is termed the assembly of the wicked (Psalm 26:5; Revelation 3:9). The second is more special, signifying the whole multitude of those who are generally esteemed by calling and outward profession. The third is most special and most proper, betokening that part which is compacted of men ordained unto eternal life.

II. The Church Militant and Triumphant

The Church is considered according unto its twofold estate: militant upon the earth, or triumphant in the heavens.

Junius saith: The former is called the Church militant, for that, struggling in this world beneath the cross against sin, the world, and Satan, it fighteth with spiritual arms, encompassing all the faithful who abide in life. The latter is triumphant, which in the heavenly fatherland doth triumph over all these.

Ames saith: The Church is divided into members according to the degrees of communion it hath with Christ, in respect whereof it is named either militant or triumphant. The Church militant is that which is partaker only of communion begun, and so yet wrestleth with foes in the field of this world (1 Corinthians 13:9,12): “We know in part, and we prophesy in part. For now we see through a glass, darkly.” (2 Corinthians 10:3): “The weapons of our warfare.” (Ephesians 6:12): “We wrestle... therefore take unto you the whole armor of God.” The Church triumphant is that which is already perfected (Ephesians 4:13): “Till we all come... unto a perfect man, unto the measure of the stature of the fullness of Christ.” (1 Corinthians 15:24): “When that which is perfect is come.”

III. God Always Hath a Church in the World

Moreover, God ever hath some Church in the world.

Junius saith: Forasmuch as Christ is the eternal King, and His kingdom is perpetual, it is necessary that there should always be some who, accounting themselves subjects, acknowledge Him as King. Wherefore, from the first creation, there hath ever been a certain company of men elected by God who worshipped the true God. We maintain that this Church shall be perpetual and can never wholly fail, albeit Satan assayeth all things and contriveth naught that he deemeth not pertinent to the destruction and ruin of this Church. And verily, how could He be an eternal King unless He had an eternal kingdom to govern alway, and subjects to rule perpetually?

Walaeus saith: This was of old denied by the Donatists, who would have it that the Church had perished from the whole world save a corner of Africa. The opinion of the Anabaptists and other Libertines is nigh the same, who grant that the whole Church may perish. Even the Remonstrants concede that the death of Christ might have lacked all saving effect among men, and it might have come to pass that none believed. But these are confuted by the arguments following:

I. From divine promises (Jeremiah 31:36): “If these ordinances depart from before me, saith the Lord, then the seed of Israel also shall cease from being a nation before me forever.” (Isaiah 55:10): “As the rain cometh down, and the snow from heaven, and returneth not thither, but watereth the earth... so shall my word be that goeth forth out of my mouth: it shall not return unto me void.” (Matthew 16:18): “The gates of hell shall not prevail against it.” (Matthew 28:20): “Lo, I am with you always.”

II. From the nature of Christ the King. Christ is the eternal King, Bridegroom, Shepherd, Priest, and Head of His Church; therefore, He shall never be without His kingdom, without His flock, without His bride, without His body, which He quickeneth and for which He intercedeth. Hence we believe in the Catholic Church.

III. For that every one of the saved must be a true member of the Catholic Church. As in Galatians 4:26, Jerusalem above is called the mother of us all. Thus, as none is a son of God who hath not God as Father, so neither is any save he who hath the Church as mother. To him to whom the Church is not mother, God is not Father. These and many like things prove that God alway hath a Church upon earth, by which He is worshipped and which He doth enliven.

IV. The Church: Universal and Particular

And it is universal or particular.

Junius saith: The attributes of the Church are commonly set forth as four: that it is one, holy, apostolic, and catholic. It is one by the institution of God; holy by the benefit of Christ calling unto purification from sins, indeed in true holiness, yet, whilst it wrestleth with sin in this world, imperfect; apostolic in the truth of doctrine, for it is built upon the foundation of the apostles and prophets, whose foundation is Christ; finally, catholic:

I. By reason of places and persons: for it is not bound to any certain place or certain succession.

II. By reason of time, for it is circumscribed by no time.

III. By reason of parts, which, without any circumscription of time and place, are reckoned to pertain unto it.

Ames saith: This Church is mystically one, not generically, but as the most special species or individual, for it hath no species properly so called. Therefore, it is termed catholic, not as katholou signifying a genus or something general, but as denoting something integrally universal (as when we say the whole world), for it embraceth the faithful of all nations, all places, and all times. Hence, no part of the Church can truly be called catholic save insofar as it professeth that faith which is the faith of the Catholic Church. In this sense, the ancients called not only that part of the Church which was at Rome, but others also, catholic. Thus, our Franeker Church may rightly be called catholic insofar as it professeth that faith which is of the Catholic Church.

V. The Means by Which Christ Gathereth the Church

The means or instrument whereby Christ gathereth the Church is the preaching of the Gospel.

Trelcatius saith: The instrumental and administrative cause of the Church is, generally, the word of God, revealed and communicated in any wise, whether inwardly or outwardly, or both together (Hebrews 4:12; Acts 2:4; 2 Peter 2:23; 1 Timothy 3:15). Whence the word is called the seed of the Church, and the rule, measure, and foundation of the truth, which the Church holdeth as if suspended on a pillar and upholdeth as a foundation, as it is named in the Scriptures. More specially, the instrumental cause of the invisible Church is faith itself, which, being internal, is not known by human judgment, yet designateth the true and essential nature and form of a member of the Church, as the sole instrument of that internal and effectual divine calling. Of the visible Church, the chief and primary cause is the heralds of the word, who are therefore called builders and architects in the Scriptures (1 Corinthians 3:10; Ephesians 4:12), instruments occupied by God and the Lord Jesus Christ for the fitting together of the saints, for the work of the ministry, and for the common edification of the body of Christ (Ephesians 4:7; 2 Corinthians 4:1).

Ames saith: But since the Spirit Himself doth inwardly and most intimately, and thus in His own manner immediately, apply all saving things unto us, and no external means is properly capable of that power whereby grace is really communicated unto us, therefore these means, albeit they morally concur and operate in preparing man to receive that grace, yet do not properly confer grace itself, but the Spirit who worketh together with them (1 Corinthians 3:7).

VI. The Church: Visible and Invisible

Moreover, according unto its twofold aspect, either internal or external, the Church is said to be visible or invisible.

Junius saith: The Church militant in this world is said to be partly visible, partly invisible: visible with respect to its matter and external form, and also by reason of its external polity; invisible with respect to its internal form, for those who dwell on earth and live in particular churches cannot be discerned by any judgment of the senses whether they truly belong unto the Catholic Church. We see men, indeed, and particular churches wherein they live; but which among them are elect, which are truly faithful, this cannot be certainly established by any judgment of the eyes. The matter of the visible Church is men, not only those who are substantially of the Church by effectual calling and who are in it both in heart and body, but generally all the called (Matthew 22:14), approaching the communion of the Church by the preaching of the Gospel. Wherefore, we deny not that hypocrites are materially and bodily in the Church (Matthew 7:22), for in the constitution of the Church, the profane do cautiously enter with the pious. Whence Augustine wisely saith, “Many wolves are in this fold with whom...” Therefore, this Church is likened unto the flock of Ezekiel 34:17, where sheep and goats are together; to the net of Matthew 13:47, wherein are good and bad fish; to the floor of Matthew 3:12, where wheat is mingled with chaff; to the wedding of Matthew 22:10, where good and bad recline; and to the very great house of 2 Timothy 2:20, wherein are divers vessels.

Ames saith: The Church militant is both invisible and visible: visible, that is, by external sight or sense. This distinction is not a distribution of a genus into species, as though there were one visible Church and another invisible, nor of a whole into parts, as if one part of the Church were visible and another invisible, but a distinction of adjuncts of the same subject. For invisibility is an affection or mode of the Church with respect to its essential and internal form; visibility is an affection or mode of the Church with respect to its accidental and external form. The essential form is invisible, for it is a relation which falleth not under sense, and also spiritual, and thus more remote from sense than many other relations. The accidental form is visible, for it is naught else but the external profession of internal faith, which may easily be perceived by sense.

VII. The Church Is Known by Certain Marks

And so the Church is discerned by its certain marks.

Maccovius saith: Moreover, the marks whereby the Church is made visible are those which are called kata sēmeia, not tekmēria. The reason hereof is that all the marks of the Church which fall under the senses are common to all the pious with hypocrites. Therefore, the marks of the Church serve us not to know distinctly who belong unto the Church, but to know with whom we should cultivate communion, whether public or private—namely, with those in whom these marks are present, whence by the judgment of charity it may be gathered that they are the true Church or belong unto the true Church. For albeit from these marks it is not gathered precisely who belong unto the Church of God, yet it is certain that the Church is only in this kind of men to whom these marks pertain. For we know that it cannot be that in this multitude of men who hear the word of God and receive the same sacraments, all are ungodly, for the word of God, if not in all, yet in some, is effectual. But now we must show that there are certain marks of the Church, and this against the Socinians, who deny that such are given. Secondly, we must declare what those marks be. And indeed, that there are marks of the Church, Scripture demonstrateth, and the nature of the thing. Scripture affirmeth this when it teacheth that those who are truly good must be made manifest; therefore, they are hidden by nature and are not manifested, which are set in the open, but which are secret and concealed. “It is necessary,” saith Paul (1 Corinthians 11:19), “that there be heresies among you, that they which are approved may be made manifest.” There is, therefore, a mark whereby the pious are distinguished. Moreover, only the pious make the body of Christ and the Church. Then, 2 Corinthians 3:3, “Ye are manifestly declared,” concerning the Corinthians, whom he saith are known as those who truly believed in Christ; thus, the truly faithful are marked by certain signs which, when they are evident to human eyes, designate the faithful. Yet the same Apostle teacheth (2 Timothy 2:19), “The Lord knoweth who are His,” that is, only the Lord knoweth, for it is the same expression as “Thou shalt worship God, thou shalt serve God,” which Christ rendered, “Thou shalt worship God, and Him only shalt thou serve.” And the nature of the thing requireth the same, for how could there be any communion among the faithful if there were no marks whereby they might mutually recognize one another? And again, if we were certainly aware of the mind of men, what their spirit is, those who are truly faithful could be distinctly and certainly known. Therefore, the faithful can be distinguished, and they cannot be distinguished. That is, they are distinguished, so to speak, by conjectural judgment, as far as the human mind can perceive; we know who are faithful and who are less so, but by certain judgment, only God knoweth that. Thus, the Apostle calleth the internal state of the soul “the hidden things of the heart,” and Peter calleth it “the hidden man.” For each one is conscious of himself, whence that of John: “By this we know that we are the sons of God and thankful to God, if we love our brethren.” And the Spirit of God together with our spirit testifieth (Romans 8:16) that we are the sons of God. But no one is conscious of another’s conscience unless it revealeth itself. But in hypocrites, it draweth a veil over itself, and so hypocrites cannot certainly be distinguished from the pious.

VIII. The Principal Mark of the Church

The principal mark of the Church is the profession of true doctrine; unto which are added the lawful use of the sacraments and of ecclesiastical discipline, and the piety and holiness of the church members.

Trelcatius saith: The form distinguishing and discriminating the true visible Church from the false is that which certain marks circumscribe and designate. We call marks those things whereby matters in question are certainly known, whether perceptible by sense, by intellect, or by both. As there is wont to be a twofold knowledge of anything—one which designateth its essence through true and immediate causes, the other derived from accidents and indicating either its inseparable affections or other external accidents which only surround the thing—so unto this twofold knowledge correspond two kinds of marks. For some marks are essential and necessary, which are called tekmēria; others are accidental, which are called eikota. The former are the proper arguments of the Church, which certainly demonstrate its essence and nature; the latter are its common and probable indications. The proper and essential mark of the visible Church, regarding its essence immediately, properly, and proximately flowing from its form, is singular: namely, the truth of the word of God revealed and communicated, unto which the truth of the sacraments is inseparably conjoined as connected (Hebrews 4:12; John 10:27; Matthew 28:19; Romans 4:11). For the truth of both is such a proper and essential tekmērion of the Church that this truth and the Church are equally convertible. The accidental marks are twofold: some are drawn from the inseparable affections of the Church, which are also the affections of its primary mark: the pure preaching of the word and the lawful administration of the sacraments (John 5:39; Acts 17:11; Matthew 26:26; 1 Corinthians 16:17). These twain are necessary and proper adjuncts and attributes of the Church; others regard the order in the Church, whether public or private, properly, such as ecclesiastical power and public or private exercises of piety and charity.

Ames saith: The profession of true faith is the most essential mark of the Church. This profession in some assembly of the faithful can precede the solemn preaching of the word and the administration of the sacraments.

Maccovius saith: The marks of the Catholic Church are twain: the preaching of the divine word and the lawful use of the sacraments. And that the preaching of the divine word and profession is the most certain and evident mark of the Church of Christ, many places of Scripture teach us; we shall bring forth a few out of many. Acts 2:41: “They that gladly received his word were baptized: and the same day there were added unto them about three thousand souls.” The same is clear from Matthew 28:19: “Go ye therefore, and teach all nations”; therefore, the beginning of the Church is preaching, and hence it is established that someone is called if he receiveth the word of God. Likewise, the Apostle saith that the faithful are built upon the foundation of the prophets and apostles, whence it is established that the Church is known from the foundation of the prophets and apostles, as the firmness of a building is known from its foundation. We also affirm that the sacraments and their lawful use are the second mark of the Church. For when Christ sent the apostles to gather the Church, He gave them commands to teach and to baptize (Matthew 28:19); where these are done, there is the Church. “They were baptized,” saith Luke, “and there were added unto the Church that day about three thousand souls”; therefore, from baptism, we know who is added unto the Church. Moreover, it should here be noted that among these marks there is this difference: the word of God is simply a necessary mark, for where the word of God is not, the Church cannot be; but the use of the sacraments is not simply and absolutely necessary, but may be omitted for a time, while the Church remaineth safe and sound. This can be confirmed by the example of the Israelite Church, wherein we read that circumcision was omitted for forty years because of their continual wandering.

Walaeus saith: 

I. If error in doctrine and pertinacity in the same error be a certain mark of a heretical and impure Church, then it is certain that purity of doctrine and orthodoxy be a true and certain mark of the true Church. The antecedent is beyond controversy among all and is proved by evident places of Scripture where we are commanded to beware of them, as Matthew 16:6: “Take heed and beware of the leaven,” that is, the false doctrine of the Pharisees. 1 John 4:1: “Try the spirits whether they are of God: because many false prophets are gone out into the world.”

II. That is a true, proper, and essential mark of the Church which is a true mark of the covenant of God initiated and confirmed with some people; for the covenant of God with some people constituteth the Church, as Genesis 17:7: “I will be your God, and the God of your seed.” “Blessed is the nation whose God is the Lord” (Psalm 33:12; 65:4). But from the true tables of the covenant communicated unto some people, it is certainly established that God hath made a covenant with some people. Therefore, etc. That the tables of the covenant are the word of God, and the signs of that covenant are the sacraments themselves, is beyond all controversy among all Christians and is proved by many places of Sacred Scripture, as Isaiah 59:21: “This is my covenant with them, saith the Lord; My spirit that is upon thee, and my words which I have put in thy mouth, shall not depart out of thy mouth, nor out of the mouth of thy seed, nor out of the mouth of thy seed’s seed, from henceforth and forever.” Thus also God said (Exodus 34:27): “Write thou these words: for after the tenor of these words I have made a covenant with thee and with Israel.” And therefore, throughout Scripture, the word itself is called the covenant of God, and the tables of the law, the tables of the covenant, and the sacraments, the signs of the covenant (Exodus 24:7; 34:28; Deuteronomy 5:2; 9:11, etc.).

III. That is a true mark of the Church according unto whose form churches are first erected and, when fallen, restored. But according unto the norm of the word of God alone are churches first erected and, when fallen, restored; therefore, etc. The major is self-evident. For whence can the Church be better known than from the norm according unto which it is erected? As the straightness of a wall being erected or restored is known from the application of the norm. Therefore, the agreement of the norm with the building or wall is the best mark of straightness. The minor is certain from the examples of the erection and restoration of all churches. Thus speaketh Christ (Matthew 28:19; Mark 16:15): “Go ye, teach all nations, baptizing them in the name of the Father,” etc. Likewise, “teach them to observe all things whatsoever I have commanded you.” Thus, Romans 10:17: “Faith is by hearing, and hearing by the word of God.” Therefore, Ephesians 2:20: we are said to be “built upon the foundation of the apostles and prophets.” Therefore, 1 Peter 1:23: it is called the seed by which we are begotten again, and so James 1:18. Of the restoration of churches, there are divers examples in the Old and New Testaments, as Joshua 5:1; 24:14. Joshua, to correct and erect again the Israelite Church, commandeth the people to be circumcised and bindeth them by oath to keep God’s commandments and to guard His word. So also Josiah (2 Kings 23:21; 2 Chronicles 34:32), commandeth the worship to be renewed according to the law and the Passover to be celebrated. So Nehemiah 8:2; Ezra 7:10. So 1 Corinthians 11:23: “I have received of the Lord that which also I delivered unto you.” Likewise, Galatians 1:6: “Who hath bewitched you into another gospel, where there is none?” So Revelation 2:2; 3:2.

IV. Those are true marks of the Church from which the sheep of Christ are known and distinguished from the goats. But from obedience rendered unto the word of God, the sheep of Christ are known, etc. The minor is proved (John 8:47): “He that is of God heareth God’s word: ye therefore hear them not, because ye are not of God.” Likewise, John 10:4: “The sheep hear his voice, and follow him, for they know his voice; and a stranger will they not follow, but will flee from him, for they know not the voice of strangers.” 1 John 4:5, speaking of deceiving spirits: “They are of the world, therefore speak they of the world, and the world heareth them. We are of God: he that knoweth God heareth us; he that is not of God heareth not us. Hereby know we the spirit of truth and the spirit of error.”

V. Those are true marks of the Church from which the churches themselves and the true members of the Church are described and commended. But from the reception and obedience of the Gospel, churches are oft described and commended; therefore, etc. The major is evident, for that is the property of signs, that the thing is designated by them. The minor is proved by many places of Scripture, as Acts 2:41: Peter, having delivered his sermon, exhorted them to faith and repentance, and it is added, “Then they that gladly received his word were baptized: and the same day there were added unto them about three thousand souls, and they continued steadfastly in the apostles’ doctrine and fellowship, and in breaking of bread, and in prayers.” So Ephesians 1:13: “In whom ye also trusted, after that ye heard the word of truth, the gospel of your salvation.” So Colossians 1:6: “The gospel is come unto you, as it is in all the world; and bringeth forth fruit,” etc. So 1 Thessalonians 1:6; 2:13: “For this cause also thank we God without ceasing, because, when ye received the word of God which ye heard of us, ye received it not as the word of men, but as it is in truth, the word of God, which effectually worketh also in you that believe.”

IX. The Purity of the Church

And according as those marks agree more or less, the Church is purer or more impure.

Trelcatius saith: And of all these marks, there is a common usurpation, and their external appearance is well-nigh in all churches; but the right of possession and lawful use of them is proper and particular only unto the true Church. Hence, judgment must be made concerning the purity or impurity, the clarity or obscurity of the visible Church. For that Church which hath the essential mark and all the accidental ones is most pure; that which hath only the essential one, not all the accidental ones, is a true Church but imperfect; that which hath some of the accidental ones, not the essential one, is a Church equivocally called or hypocritical. That which hath neither is not even a Church.

Walaeus saith: The Church is either pure or impure; the impure again is either erring, or schismatic, or heretical. A heretical Church is one that pertinaciously maintaineth error in the foundation of faith. Such were the Samosatenian, Arian, Pelagian, etc. In the ancient Church, a difference was established between heresies and heresies; therefore, the baptism of some was repeated because they openly denied the divinity of the Son and destroyed the form of baptism, such as the Samosatenians, Valentinians, Gnostics, Marcionites, etc., who did not baptize according to the form instituted by Christ. Others who did not directly but by consequence deny these and preserved the integral form of baptism were not rebaptized, such as the Arians, Pelagians, etc. See the First Council of Nicaea, Canon 19, where a definition was issued about the Paulianists fleeing to the Catholic Church, that they be baptized; see Plessis, De Ecclesia, p. 31. Schismatic is that which indeed doth not pertinaciously err in faith but, against charity, because of blemishes in life or deeds or in the observation of order, separateth itself from the true Church; such was that of the Donatists and Novatians, who separated themselves from the Church because of the lapses of others. And this again is either purely schismatic or mixed, for error in doctrine is usually joined to schism. The cause, not the separation, maketh the schism, say the Canonists. Thus, the Apostles were not schismatics when they separated from the Pharisees, but the Pharisees themselves were. In pure schism, it is necessary to distinguish the authors of the schism from the body itself which is seduced by them; the latter have greater excuse, although neither are without blame. Thus, Dathan with his followers, who separated from Aaron, was punished by God. However, as in political schism, the king punisheth the authors and spareth the people, so it is to be hoped that in schism also it will be so with God (Plessis, p. 35). An erring Church is one that indeed maintaineth some errors but not against the foundation. Concerning which distinction, the Apostle treateth in 1 Corinthians 3:12, where he compareth those errors to hay and stubble.

X. The False Marks of the Church

But the genuine marks of the Church are not those which the Papists deliver, such as antiquity, multitude, etc.

Junius saith: Wherefore, antiquity, multitude, local succession are not tekmēria of the Church. For:

I. They are not essential unto it.

II. They are common to truth and falsehood.

III. They need proof and approval from the true marks.

Walaeus saith: Most Papists establish these, namely, antiquity, multitude, personal and local succession, miracles, and revelations. It must be observed that all these marks agree with Antichristianism:

I. Antiquity, for the mystery of iniquity was already working from the time of the Apostles.

II. Multitude and efficacy of doctrine, for the whole world followeth the beast.

III. Succession, for he will sit in the temple of God, also he sitteth upon the seven-hilled city.

IV. Miracles and revelations, for he will come with the working of signs, etc.

V. Unity, for the whole world will worship the beast and be drunk with the cup of fornication of the kings of the earth.

VI. Holiness and firmness, for she sitteth as a queen and will not be a widow; also, she hath horns like a lamb.

VII. Victories, for he will make war against the saints and prevail (Revelation 11:5; 12:11).

XI. The Church Must Be Discerned by Its Marks

Therefore, the Church is discerned by its marks, that one may truly join himself unto its communion.

Junius saith: Since, therefore, God willeth that His Son be acknowledged in the world, and that from the human race a peculiar people be chosen (Luke 12:32; 14:22-23), by whom He is invoked, and that He declare His gracious will in the Church, wherein the voice of the Gospel soundeth and the divine ministry is seen, through which God revealeth Himself and worketh, we ought by duty to submit ourselves unto it, which we see occupied in building the body of Christ and in polishing living stones. Wherefore, they err grievously and cast themselves into condemnation who disdain to give their name unto any Church and to hear it teaching from the word of God (Matthew 10:40), to join their confession and invocation with prayers and the invocation of the Church itself with one accord, and to participate in the holy Supper, whereby the memory of Christ is celebrated; whether they abstain from that sacred action, instituted for all imbued with Christian faith, by contempt, or by negligence, or by error, not of the mind, I say, but of the will.

Ames saith: Because the institutions of Christ always have the blessing of God conjoined, therefore divers promises of God are made unto the Church concerning the presence of Christ (Matthew 18:20; 1 Corinthians 5:4), so that in a singular way He is said to walk and dwell in the churches (Revelation 2:1; Isaiah 31:9), and concerning the presence of the Holy Spirit (Isaiah 59:21), so that a greater and more certain blessing of God may be expected in the Church instituted by God than in any solitary life. Therefore, those who have opportunity to join themselves unto the Church and neglect it sin most grievously, not only against God by reason of the institution but also against their own souls by reason of the blessing annexed. And if they obstinately persist in that neglect, whatever else they profess, they can hardly be accounted as faithful truly seeking the kingdom of God.

Walaeus saith: Yet there are some, especially in our country, who, following Cornbert, acknowledge indeed some Church, not however conjoined or united, but separate members living here and there, without the preaching of the word, without sacraments, without discipline, etc., saying that it sufficeth to conceive faith from the reading of Scripture, to live piously, and to cultivate spiritual communion with the Church that was in the time of the Apostles. Yea, they proceed so far that rather than suffer for the truth, they dissemble it and conform themselves to others in external rites. But this opinion is not alien to Libertinism and fighteth against the Scriptures:

I. For God hath expressly said that the preaching of the word and the use of the sacraments shall always endure in the Church, as Ephesians 4:11. So 1 Corinthians 11:26. Therefore, He instituted the ministry itself to endure even after the time of the Apostles (1 Timothy 3:1; Titus 1:5), and prescribeth rules of calling, always of the same kind, and among others that they be able to teach and admonish. So 1 Peter 5:2: “Feed the flock of God which is among you.”

II. From divine commands and promises concerning the singular blessing of God toward those who are gathered in His name (Matthew 18:20): “Where two or three are gathered together in my name,” etc. (Hebrews 10:25): “Not forsaking the assembling of ourselves together, as the manner of some is; but exhorting one another.” The Church is the house of the living God (1 Timothy 3:15), wherein He dwelleth by His Spirit and grace (Psalm 46:5; 2 Corinthians 6:16).

III. From the reproofs of the Holy Spirit when ministers perform not their office, as is seen throughout the Apostolic Epistles, and especially Revelation 2 and 3, where the Holy Spirit reproveth the angels of the churches because they tolerate evil men and separate them not from their body. So also 1 Corinthians 5:2: “Put away from among yourselves that wicked person.” And the general law of discipline in the Church of Christ is ever enduring (Matthew 18:18): “Tell it unto the church: but if he neglect to hear the church, let him be unto thee as an heathen man and a publican. Verily I say unto you, Whatsoever ye shall bind on earth shall be bound in heaven: and whatsoever ye shall loose on earth shall be loosed in heaven.”

IV. From the use and necessity of the word and sacraments: for faith is by hearing, and how shall they believe unless it be preached? etc. (Romans 10:14,17). By baptism, we are grafted into Christ (Romans 6:3; Galatians 3:27). By the Supper, we have communion with Christ (1 Corinthians 10:16). Hence, the pious greatly complain when they are compelled to abstain from the assembly of the saints, as David (Psalm 42:4; 84:1). By the word, we are begotten again (1 Peter 1:23; James 1:18).

These arguments demonstrate that the Church is not such an assembly as they imagine:

I. For what they object, that from the time of the Apostles the Church hath failed, hath already been refuted.

II. That they say God can be worshipped outside the assembly, I acknowledge to be true; but the assembly is not instituted and commanded by Christ in vain, nor the word, nor the sacraments, nor discipline, as we have seen above; and therefore, He willeth that He be worshipped also in the assembly.

III. We worship God in spirit. Response: God willeth to be worshipped in spirit and in body (Romans 12:1; 1 Corinthians 6:20). Nor would it have been necessary for them to have undergone martyrdom for the truth if only internal worship sufficed, as they imagine. Finally, it cannot be that anyone rightly worshippeth God in spirit who doth not celebrate Him with external confession (Romans 10:10): “With the heart man believeth unto righteousness; and with the mouth confession is made unto salvation.”

XII. Communion of Saints in the Church

The communion of saints in the Church is with Christ and among themselves.

Junius saith: The communion of saints is a relative act placed in ordination, application, and conformation of individual members with their head and among themselves, proceeding from that most holy union whereby the Church is one, to testify eternally unto the glory of God in the kingdom of Christ and our salvation. We call it a relative act, not a power, whereby individual members truly communicate with Christ and among themselves, both by perceiving and by delivering, in all things pertaining unto their own and others’ perfection, both singularly and universally. I. In order, as some are members of others, and each in their order and place under one head, Christ. II. In application, whereby they communicate unto others, delivering and receiving all offices which that august necessity of union in Christ commandeth to be communicated. III. In conformation, whereby each is conformably informed by Christ and prepareth himself for common conformation. And this is the true reason which Paul describeth, saying that we grow up into Him who is the head, that is, Christ, from whom the whole body fitly joined together and compacted by every joint of supply, according to the effectual working in the measure of every part, maketh increase of the body unto the edifying of itself in love, which all God worketh in all (Ephesians 4:15-16). The parts of this communion are twain. For the first is the communion of saints with Christ as the head of all; the second, of the saints among themselves.

Ames saith: This relation is so intimate that by reason thereof, not only is Christ of the Church and the Church of Christ (Song of Solomon 2:16), but also Christ is in the Church, and the Church in Him (John 15:4; 1 John 3:24), so that the Church is mystically called Christ (1 Corinthians 12:12), and the fullness of Christ (Ephesians 1:23). Hence, the Church is metaphorically called the bride, and Christ the bridegroom; the Church a city, and Christ the King; the Church a house, and Christ the householder; the Church branches, and Christ the vine; finally, the Church the body, and Christ the head. By these comparisons, not only is the union and communion signified which is between Christ and the Church, but also the reason of order, whereby Christ is unto the Church the principle of all dignity, life, virtue, and perfection.

XIII. Christ Alone Is the Head of the Church

For Christ is the sole head of His Church.

Trelcatius saith: As the condition of the head above its body consisteth chiefly in three things—in order, perfection, and virtue: order toward the members, perfection in itself, virtue toward the whole body—so Christ, by order, perfection, and virtue, in the most excellent manner performeth all offices which can and ought to be performed by the best head toward its body. By order, for that as true God and true man, He holdeth the primacy in all things, having preeminence not only of dignity but also of government and power. Whence, existing before all things and placed above all, Scripture frequently saith. By perfection, for that Christ alone is the supreme King, Prophet, and Priest, having all things in Himself from the Father which can in no wise be required for the perfection of the head. By virtue and efficacy, for that He alone inspireth vigor, sense, motion, and spiritual life into His members, and He alone is joined unto the body by the bond of the Spirit, providing that whole structure or fitting together of the members among themselves and with God unto the whole Church.

XIV. The Roman Pope as Antichrist

But the Roman Pope, who is called the head of the Church, by that very fact proveth himself to be Antichrist.

Gomarus saith: “Antichrist” is a Greek word, not indeed by author, but by its parts and the analogy of their composition. For the author, by the inspiration of the Holy Spirit, is John the Apostle (1 John 2:18,22; 4:3; 2 John 7), who first and alone used it in the sacred letters. But by reason of the use of the word in the sacred letters, it declareth, generally or specially, the contrary unto Christ, our Savior. In the former way, it denoteth any deserter and adversary of Christ (1 John 2:18,22; 2 John 7). Whence Jerome, in Matthew 24, saith that all heresiarchs are Antichrists and, under the name of Christ, teach things contrary unto Christ. In the latter way, kat’ exochēn and (as Damascene, Orthodox Faith, Book 4, Chapter 27, speaketh of this matter) idioprōtōs kai exairetōs, in a peculiar and eminent manner, it is used of that notable one, greater than the rest (Augustine, Against the Adversary of the Law, Book 2, Chapter 12), and of the order and assembly of Antichrists (1 John 2:18; 4:3).

Professor saith: Indeed, the Bishop and Pope of Rome, whilst he hesitateth not to call himself and to behave as the Lord, King, Monarch, Bridegroom, and Husband, Head and Foundation of the universal Church of God and Christ, and also the vicar of God on earth, and the universal Bishop or Bishop of Bishops, and asserteth that this must be believed for salvation, by that very fact demonstrateth himself to be truly Antichrist, as one who invadeth the supreme power properly belonging unto Christ and maketh himself His consort, preferring himself unto the Church of God and his fellow servants. The Apostle predicteth that he will sit in the temple of God and exalt himself above all that is called God or that is worshipped (2 Thessalonians 2:4).

Spanheim saith: The characteristics of Antichrist may be reduced unto two heads: either they pertain unto the circumstances to be observed around Antichrist, or unto his qualities and acts. The circumstances to be observed around Antichrist are either of time when or of place where he is to be exhibited. The circumstance of time is likewise to be subdivided into the time of his rise, the time of his manifestation, and the time of his duration. The time of Antichrist’s rise is controverted; some affirm that Antichrist hath already risen, others deny it but contend that he will rise only at the end of the world. And here the Pseudochristian Church establisheth concerning Antichrist what the Jewish Church established concerning Christ. The affirmative opinion, that Antichrist hath already risen, is proved by Scripture: for one, when Paul teacheth that in his time he had already begun to grow (2 Thessalonians 2:6,8): “The mystery of iniquity doth already work.” The same is in 1 John 2:18; 4:3: “Even now is it in the world.” And because a “mystery” is ascribed unto him, and indeed of iniquity, opposed unto the mystery of godliness (1 Timothy 3:16), it is clear that his rise was mysterious, and thus hidden, not open, with Satan, the architect of this mystery, already in the time of the Apostles, through divers forerunners and divers preparations, laying the foundations of that great apostasy which afterward followed. For “mystery” among the Greeks is what is rightly performed, and doubtless the word itself hath a Hebrew origin, from satar, which is to hide. Thus, the life of Antipater, filled with clandestine crimes, is called kakias mystērion by Josephus (Wars of the Jews, Book 2, Chapter 17). But as Scripture distinguisheth the time of Christ’s birth and of His manifestation (Luke 1:80), so also it distinguisheth the time of Antichrist’s manifestation, teaching that he is then to be revealed when “that which withholdeth” is taken out of the way (2 Thessalonians 2:7-8). And what that “withholding” is and of what kind, the Greek scholia most conveniently explain, saying that it is the Roman Empire and kingdom, which was an obstacle, as pleased most of the ancients, Tertullian, Chrysostom, Oecumenius, Theophylact, and others. The same is expressly taught by the Holy Spirit in Revelation 13 and 17, where he describeth the manifestation of Antichrist only after the occupation of the Roman Empire by ten kings. The terms of Antichrist’s duration are likewise explained by the Holy Spirit when He teacheth that he is not only to be consumed by the spirit of Christ’s mouth but also to be abolished by the brightness of His coming. There is a twofold period: the former of inchoate destruction, the latter of consummate destruction of Antichrist (2 Thessalonians 2:8). Nor is it obscure that by “the brightness of His coming” is designated the illustrious coming kat’ antonomasian, such as cannot be more illustrious than that which will one day be on that decisive day. From which circumstance of time, it is clear that Antichrist cannot be established as one person or one singular man without grave absurdity, since the duration attributed unto Antichrist cannot belong unto one man. And it is a mere fiction that Antichrist will reign only for three and a half years, designated by “a time, times, and half a time,” which are resolved into 42 months or 1260 days, from Daniel 8:25; 12:7; Revelation 12:6,14. For what is read in Daniel pertaineth not directly unto Antichrist, nor can it be proved in Revelation 13:5 that the days are to be understood mathematically rather than prophetically for so many years. Nor indeed can those things attributed unto Antichrist be accomplished in so short a number of years and days with any probability. Concerning the circumstance of place, Scripture describeth unto us the seat of Antichrist both generally and particularly. Generally, that Antichrist will sit in the temple of God (2 Thessalonians 2:4). Particularly, that he will sit in the seven-hilled city (Revelation 17:9). The characteristics drawn partly from the qualities of Antichrist, partly from his acts, are also variously represented unto us in Scripture. The qualities of Antichrist are partly internal, partly external. Internal: I. Fraudulence. II. Cruelty. External: I. Authority or dignity. II. Power. III. Riches. IV. Nomenclature.

XV. The Roman Church Hath Long Since Fallen Away

Indeed, the Roman Church hath long since fallen away and ceased to be a true Church.

Junius saith: From the foregoing, we rightly conclude that the Roman Church hath erred, and its authority cannot be equated with Sacred Scripture, and it is not the orthodox Church of Christ. For in it, neither the pure preaching of the word nor the lawful administration of the sacraments is to be seen. Nor do those marks which are established by the Papists belong unto it (Bellarmine, De Ecclesia Militante, Book 4, Chapters 3-4). For it hath neither true antiquity, duration in doctrine, amplitude of believers, succession in doctrine, conspiracy in doctrine with the primitive Church, nor others.

Walaeus saith:

Objection: But doth the Papal Church now err against the foundations of salvation? And are none gained for Christ through the ministry that soundeth there?

Response: The Papacy must be distinguished from the Church which lay hidden in the Papacy, as we see in 2 Thessalonians 2:4. For the son of perdition sitteth in the temple of God. Therefore, we deny that the Papacy is the Church, that is, the Roman hierarchy with its superstitions; yet we see that sometimes some arise in the Papacy who teach more purely, instruct others, and gain for Christ through the spirit of discretion of true doctrine from false. And the members of the Church themselves, from hearing the word preached, wherein the foundations are oft proposed, can discern fundamental errors compared unto the same word through the same spirit of discretion; whence it cometh to pass that they then renounce the errors and oft suffer persecution from others. Whose duty it is then to go out from them, lest they become partakers of their sins. For poison is proposed there conjoined with saving doctrine; both cannot be taken together without lethal harm; if separated, one from the other, it can save.

They object: If the Roman Church hath erred for so long, therefore there was no Church in the world, or let it be said where it was.

Response: The consequence is denied:

I. For there hath always been a Church in the world, albeit not always so conspicuous; for it was preserved by God in secret places (Revelation 12:6), and yet not so hidden that the dragon and Antichrist did not persecute it.

II. Besides the Roman Church, there have always been many visible churches in the world in the East and West, which were much purer than the Papal. See Marnix, Part 3, from Chapter 10 onward. Yea, we will not even deny the title of Church unto the Papal Church itself, albeit it be a corrupt and diseased Church. Otherwise, the Pontiff would not be Antichrist, for he was to sit in the temple of God.

XVI. Any Particular Church Can Fail

Nevertheless, it cometh to pass that any particular Church can fail.

Junius saith: Meanwhile, we deny not that this or that particular Church can fail; yea, that any particular churches can be reduced unto such paucity that there is not any true visible Church of Christ publicly in the world. For we affirm that sometimes the Church loseth its external splendor, escapeth the eyes of men, and consisteth of few men, if we consider the remaining multitude; whence it is clear that the Church is not to endure perpetually and visibly in one seat. That particular churches fail from God and the truth is sufficiently clear from the example of many most flourishing churches. This failure is either by skoteidōs, when Christianity is altogether rejected, and there is apostasy into Judaism, Mohammedanism, or Paganism; or by phthora or change, when the word and seals, though greatly corrupted, remain, as in the Israelite Church, which begot sons for God by circumcision but dedicated and nourished them for the devil.

Walaeus saith: The Papists agree with us that all other visible churches can err, yea, fail. But they except only the Roman Church; the others are immune from error only insofar as they cultivate communion with it; if they fail from that communion, they are subject unto error. And therefore, they acknowledge it alone as Catholic; and when they are more closely pressed, that whole and splendid name of the Catholic Church is finally contracted unto the Pontiff alone, who alone is free from error when he teacheth from the chair. This is what the Holy Spirit noteth in Revelation, that the Babylonian harlot, drunk with the blood of the saints, who sitteth upon the beast, that is, the seven-hilled city, will glory in this: “I sit a queen, and am no widow, and shall see no sorrow” (Revelation 18:7). Just as the former external Babylon also gloried (Isaiah 47:8). Therefore, let us examine the arguments on both sides:

I. If the external and visible Church of the Old Testament could err and fail from the faith, then there is no reason why the same should not be said and established concerning any Church of the New Testament. The antecedent can be demonstrated by many examples and places of Scripture; therefore, the consequent is certain. To weaken the force of this major, some Papists respond that the consequence is not firm because the Church of the New Testament resteth on better and more certain promises than the old Synagogue (for so they are wont contemptuously to speak of it): namely, the promises are Matthew 16:18: “The gates of hell shall not prevail against it.” Likewise, 1 Timothy 3:15: “The pillar and ground of the truth,” etc. Response:

  1. None of these promises was made unto the Roman Church, since not a jot here existeth about it, and therefore the other churches founded by Peter and the other Apostles could equally infer the same from this, if these were said of the visible and particular Church.
  2. It is false that the Church of the Old Testament, and namely the Jerusalem Church, did not have equally firm promises (2 Samuel 7:16): “Thy house and thy kingdom shall be established forever before thee: thy throne shall be established forever.” (Psalm 132:13-14): “The Lord hath chosen Zion; he hath desired it for his habitation. This is my rest forever: here will I dwell; for I have desired it.” (Isaiah 49:14, etc.): “But Zion said, The Lord hath forsaken me, and my Lord hath forgotten me. Can a woman forget her sucking child, that she should not have compassion on the son of her womb? yea, they may forget, yet will I not forget thee. Behold, I have graven thee upon the palms of my hands; thy walls are continually before me.” Which promises, and namely concerning Zion and the house of David and Israel, are no less manifest than those concerning the Church of the New Testament.

But that the argument from the example of the Israelite Church unto the Christian Church, yea specifically the Roman, is firm, the Apostle himself teacheth (Romans 11:19): “Thou wilt say then, The branches were broken off, that I might be grafted in. Well; because of unbelief they were broken off, and thou standest by faith. Be not highminded, but fear: for if God spared not the natural branches, take heed lest he also spare not thee.” So far is it that a less firm promise was made unto them, that from the greater the Apostle here argueth concerning the Gentile Church, and namely the Roman. Thus, the same Apostle argueth from the example of the Israelites concerning the churches of the New Testament (1 Corinthians 10:6,11): “These things were our examples, to the intent we should not lust after evil things, as they also lusted.” Thus, Peter argueth (2 Peter 2:1): “As there were false prophets among the people, so there shall be false teachers among you,” etc. The minor of this syllogism is demonstrated both by the prediction of Moses (Deuteronomy 32:15, etc.) and by many evident examples: namely, of the Israelite Church in the desert, when Aaron cast the calf (Exodus 32:1); in the times of the Judges, all Israel defected unto idolatry, as we see in the time of Gideon and other Judges (Judges 3:7; 6:31), with few exceptions who kept themselves pure among them. Afterward, in the time of Elijah (1 Kings 19:14), when he thought he alone remained; in the time of the later prophets, who everywhere complain of this, especially Isaiah (Isaiah 1:2-3): “I have nourished and brought up children, and they have rebelled against me.” (Jeremiah 10:21): “The pastors are become brutish, and have not sought the Lord: therefore they shall not prosper, and all their flocks shall be scattered.” And 50:6: “My people hath been lost sheep: their shepherds have caused them to go astray, they have turned them away on the mountains.” (Ezekiel 7:26): “The law shall perish from the priest, and counsel from the ancients.” (Ezekiel 16:51): God testifieth that Judah, by idolatry and other abominations, justified her sisters, namely the Samaritans and Sodomites; and therefore, as He had removed them, He would also remove her. (Zephaniah 3:10): “The watchmen are blind: they are all ignorant, they are all dumb dogs, they cannot bark; sleeping, lying down, loving to slumber.” And verse 12: “I will leave in the midst of thee an afflicted and poor people, and they shall trust in the name of the Lord.” Where then is the firmness of the visible Church? So in the time of the Maccabees under Antiochus; in the time of Christ, under the Pharisees and Scribes, when they condemned Christ Himself in their synagogue and, with the people, except for a few pious who were among them and as it were hidden, denied and refused Him; yea, even the Apostles themselves, walking with Christ, dreamed of a temporal kingdom of Christ and believed not in His resurrection.

II. The argument is taken from the predictions of Christ concerning the future state of the Church in later times, as Matthew 24:24: “There shall arise false Christs, and false prophets, and shall shew great signs and wonders; insomuch that, if it were possible, they shall deceive the very elect.” (Luke 18:8): “When the Son of man cometh, shall he find faith on the earth?” (2 Thessalonians 2:3): “That day shall not come, except there come a falling away first.” And that this apostasy is to be understood as a common apostasy from the faith, against those who will understand it as an apostasy from the Roman Empire, is demonstrated:

  1. For the word “apostate” and “apostasy” is never understood of any other than from the faith.
  2. For the rest that followeth explaineth it, when it saith that he will sit in the temple of God and show himself as God, that he will come with lying wonders, that God will send them strong delusion, etc.
  3. From other places that explain this, as 1 Timothy 4:1: “The Spirit speaketh expressly, that in the latter times some shall depart from the faith.” (Revelation 12:6): “The woman,” a type of the Church, “fled into the wilderness” from the persecution of the dragon. (Revelation 13:8): “All that dwell upon the earth shall worship him, whose names are not written in the book of life.” See also Revelation 17:2; 18:3.

III. From the time of the New Testament under the tenth persecution, under which the Church was so oppressed that scarcely any appeared who dared to profess the name of Christ, and Diocletian is said to have boasted that he had overthrown the Christian name: where then was that visibility of the Church of which they boast? So under Constantius and some other Arian emperors, the Roman Church itself with its bishops Liberius and Felix communicated with the Arians, and the whole world wondered that it had become Arian, as some of the ancients say; only Athanasius remained constant in the profession, who was nevertheless an exile and a fugitive. And the Papists themselves acknowledge that in the time of Antichrist, the visible Church will fail, at least to the extent that the greater part of the world will be subject unto Antichrist, and the rest will live secretly for some time.

Objection: Matthew 16:18: “Upon this rock I will build my church; and the gates of hell shall not prevail against it.”

Response: We deny that this place is to be understood of the visible Church, but of the universal and invisible Church, unto which properly belongeth this insuperable firmness, as was demonstrated before.

Objection: But it is spoken of the Church built upon Peter, that is, upon Peter.

Response: I. That the rock here is Peter, Augustine himself denieth, who understandeth it as Peter’s confession or Christ whom Peter confessed. II. Even if it were granted that the person of Peter is understood here, yet it is necessarily understood insofar as he was an Apostle, and in that respect founded many visible churches, as the Antiochene, Jerusalem, Babylonian, etc., which nevertheless all perished; he also, with the other Apostles, founded the universal and invisible Church through the doctrine of the Gospel. For it is built upon the foundation of the prophets and apostles (Ephesians 2:20), and therefore all 12 Apostles are said to have laid the foundations of the heavenly Jerusalem (Revelation 21:14), which is the invisible Church, partly militant on earth, partly reigning in heaven, as all interpreters acknowledge.

Objection: 1 Timothy 3:15: The Church is called “the pillar and ground of the truth.”

Response:

I. This is said of the Ephesian Church, which nevertheless perished.

II. Therefore, with respect to its office, it is so called: for it preserveth and propagateth the truth, as pillars are wont to hold the edicts of magistrates. So Malachi 2:7: “The priest’s lips should keep knowledge, and they should seek the law at his mouth.” “But ye have violated the covenant of your God.”

XVII. The Catholic Church Cannot Fail

Nevertheless, the Catholic Church cannot fail entirely.

Maccovius saith: Here immediately ariseth the question whether the whole Church of God can pertinaciously err in things necessary for salvation. Our adversaries say that we teach this, but this is the imposture of the adversaries, not our opinion. We hold strictly and, by God’s blessing, accurately defend that God so careth for His Church that He suffereth it not to fall into ruin, which would certainly happen if it were to pertinaciously err in things necessary for salvation. Therefore, the only question between us and the adversaries is whether it can happen, and indeed hath happened, that those who by human judgment are held to be the Church of God can err or have erred. And that this is the state of the controversy appeareth from this, that thence arose the contention between us and the adversaries, because they wished to establish the Church as judge to settle controversies in religion. But if they mean that true Church of Christ which is the bride of Christ, in vain is it established as arbiter, for it is certainly and distinctly known only unto its Bridegroom, so that an appeal unto it cannot be instituted here when it is unknown unto us. Certainly, I say, and distinctly, according unto that most celebrated saying of Scripture (2 Timothy 2:19): “The Lord knoweth them that are his.” Therefore, it is asked, as was said, whether this or that Church can err, such as the Church of the Corinthians, Galatians, Ephesians, and the like, and indeed pertinaciously, and in things necessary to be known for salvation. Which question we refer unto the treatise on the particular Church. Therefore, let us return unto the Catholic Church, concerning which we say that God so careth for it that He suffereth it not to fall into ruin, which would certainly happen if it were to pertinaciously err in things necessary for salvation. Error in those things which are necessary to be known for salvation is called fundamental error; but fundamental error is that which cannot stand with true faith and holiness. For there are two things which God requireth of us, plainly necessary unless we wish to perish: faith, without which it is impossible to please God, and holiness, without which no man shall see God.

Junius saith: Therefore, it cannot come to pass that this Church faileth from its God (Matthew 16:18), whether thou regardest God promising or the Mediator through whom all saving good things come unto us, whose merit can never dry up, or the gifts themselves with which God hath adorned us, which are without repentance (Romans 11:29). Moreover, since it is grafted into Christ by true faith and is flesh of His flesh (Ephesians 5:29-30), it will never be cut off and separated from Him.

XVIII. The Church May Become Less Visible

But it cometh to pass that the Church, through oppressions and other evils, is sometimes rendered less visible.

Junius saith: For sometimes it is conspicuous not only unto the faithful but also before the world; sometimes only unto the faithful, not before the ungrateful world, because of impiety, infidelity, injustice, and its tyrannical barbarity exerted in cruel persecutions, in which time piety toward God and charity toward neighbor hold the pious concealed, so that they hide at home (Isaiah 26:20). Sometimes, indeed, it is known only unto some, not unto individuals (1 Kings 19:10), both because of their own sins and corruption in doctrine and confusion in order, and the apostasy of many (Revelation 13:4,8,12,14; 17), and finally, the unfaithfulness of pastors (Jeremiah 14:14; 23:16,21; 30), as the series of preceding ages teacheth us.

Ames saith: This Church, which in itself is visible, with respect unto others and comparatively, is also distinguished into conspicuous and hidden. It is conspicuous when the number is greater, and the profession freer and more public. It is hidden when the number is smaller, and the profession less open, which oft happeneth because of heresies, persecutions, or profane customs prevailing. By the same reason, the Church is purer and more impure, as the profession is more perfect or imperfect. But this profession dependeth not on confession alone and the preaching of the word but also on the reception and religious obedience thereof. Although the Church is subject unto such changes and can leave any part of the world, yet it hath never totally failed nor will fail from the beginning of its collection until the end of the world. For Christ must have His kingdom perpetually in the midst of His enemies until He hath put His enemies under His feet. Yea, the Church never entirely ceaseth to be visible. For although sometimes scarcely anywhere doth a Church appear so pure that one can flee unto it in the communion of the same worship in all things, yet the Church existeth in some way visible in that very impurity of worship and profession.

Walaeus saith:

Objection: But how doth this agree with what ye teach, that the Church hath failed in faith, and a universal apostasy hath invaded the Christian world? Where then was that visible Church in which the members of the invisible Church were called and collected?

Response:

I. We concede that the Apostolic Church and that near unto the Apostles in the first few centuries was a true visible Church in which the true members of the invisible Church were called and collected.

II. Concerning those times when errors began to grow strong, not all errors crept in at the same time, but gradually, and indeed lighter ones first, and then gradually more serious ones, until Antichristianism was conceived and finally fully brought to light, which happened around the year 1000. For in those thousand years from the resurrection of Christ, Satan was bound in a certain respect. For although errors and superstitions gradually increased, yet the very foundation of salvation, namely Christ and His satisfaction and merit, and the true invocation of the one God, were preserved entire, and therefore, as long as that remained, although hay and stubble were built upon it, yet true and living members of the Church could be begotten for Christ; for God, for the sake of the foundation retained, pardoneth the sins of ignorance, as is seen in 1 Corinthians 3:15. Then, when justification by one’s own merits, such monasticism as even urged works of supererogation, and manifest idolatry in the Mass and images and saints, with persecution against the foundations laid, were received, God always raised up pious pastors who contradicted these errors and thus warned the people against them; who also began to have separate assemblies, such as the Waldensians, Wycliffites, etc., who, throughout a great part of Europe, in all ages, opposed the Papal errors, as is seen in the book entitled The Witnesses of Truth, who also in each age suffered most grievous persecutions according unto the Apostolic predictions, until at length, with the light of the Gospel more powerfully exerting itself, the Reformation followed.

From which we see that the external ministry and order instituted by Christ in the Church never entirely ceased, through which the true members of the invisible Church were gathered unto Christ.

XIX. The Roman Church Needed Reformation

The apostate Roman Church needed to be reformed from its divers errors and vices.

Zanchius saith: We have not simply and in all things defected from the Roman Church, but only in those things wherein it hath defected from the Apostolic Church, and thus from itself, the ancient and pure Church. Nor have we departed with any other mind than that, if corrected, it may return unto the former form of the Church, we also may return unto it and have communion with it in its assemblies. That this may at length happen, we pray the Lord Jesus with all our heart. For what is more desirable unto any pious man than that where we were born again by baptism, there also we may live unto the end, provided it be in the Lord? I, Hieronymus Zanchius, with my whole family, wish this to be testified unto the whole Church of Christ for all eternity.

Martyr saith: They oppose us (as it seemeth unto them) with a most firm reason, asking whether all who lived before us and under the obedience of the Roman see have perished? “Ye,” they say, “are recent and late men, since ye have appeared scarcely thirty years ago. But more than 900 years have flowed from Boniface III, whom ye make the author of the Papacy. It would be most absurd to say that during all that time all in the Christian world were condemned.” Unto this, it is said that never during all that space were there lacking men who cried out against the lies and impostures of the Papacy. Then, that the Orientals and Greeks resisted that tyranny and do not yet acknowledge the dominion of the Roman Church. Whence, not the whole Christian world, as they imagine, perished for that cause. Yea, in our Western regions, up unto Pepin and Charlemagne, the liberty of the Church stood to some extent. It must also be added that, as for the predestined, none of them perished in any age. The thief embraced Christ at the last hour, and what happened unto him is not unlike to have happened unto many others. The Spirit of Christ lacketh not ways to bring back wandering sheep unto the fold of salvation. Great, yea immense, is the embrace of divine mercy, whereby He draweth unto Himself even those who are breathing out their soul. Nor for that reason doth it happen that now we should not follow the truth revealed. But concerning the salvation or perdition of our ancestors, why are we so pressed? The same could have been opposed unto the Apostles by the Hebrews. Thus, the Samaritan woman said unto Christ that her fathers worshipped God on that mountain. Thus, the Gentiles could have asked the preachers of the Gospel of the Son of God whether all their ancestors who had not heard such doctrine perished eternally? It is not for us, when the revelation of God’s will is brought, to inquire into His judgments; let us perform our duty, leaving it unto God’s arbitration to pass sentence on our ancestors and on all men according unto the decrees of His justice. If unto our fathers not all things were revealed as unto us, and not universally, yet to some extent they will be excused because of ignorance; but our case will be much worse if, knowing what hath been demonstrated in our times, we embrace them not, so far is it that the error of our ancestors should protect us. But since the weapon of this argument is common, we will conveniently turn it against the enemies. Let them say, before Boniface III, when the Papacy was unknown in the Christian world, which they will have pertain unto the articles of faith, whether all perished who did not embrace it by faith nor obeyed the Roman see? Are also those condemned and delivered unto infernal punishments, as many as in the age of Epiphanius and Jerome thought that images should be removed from the churches? They have naught to answer; therefore, let them cease to object unto us what presseth them no less than us.

Sohnnius saith: That reformation was oft attempted in the preceding ages, especially in the churches of the West, that is, in the Papacy. For oft there arose learned men who bore witness unto the truth and refuted the Papal errors, such as Blaurer, Wycliffe, John Keisersberg, Wessel, and others, of whom it is to be seen in the Catalogue of the Witnesses of Truth. It was also once taken in Bohemia by John Hus and Jerome of Prague; yet not perfected, for the Papal tyranny still opposed them, so that they could not accomplish what they wished. But now in this age, from the year 1517, not only was the reformation of doctrine and the churches again attempted and begun, but it hath progressed hitherto. For when that Roman beast thought it had conquered and was already triumphing, with the bodies and books of Wycliffe, Hus, and Jerome of Prague burned, men learned were again divinely raised up to undertake the reformation of the churches. The authors of this reformation were Luther and Zwingli, then Melanchthon, Bucer, and others, furnished with the gifts necessary for this thing.

Walaeus saith: It is asked whence the first reformers of the Church had their calling, since no churches or pastors seem to have preceded who called or confirmed them. Some therefore think that their calling was extraordinary. And although they were not furnished with the gift of miracles, yet the efficacy of their doctrine was so great that it could be in place of all miracles, as concerning John the Baptist and certain others extraordinarily called, no miracles are read. But what can be excepted against this, that his calling was predicted in the Old Testament. It is answered by the same that their extraordinary calling was also predicted in the New Testament, who were to oppose Antichrist, as is seen in Revelation 11:13 and elsewhere. Others, however, have rightly observed that it is not necessary, for a just solution of this difficulty, to have recourse unto an extraordinary calling; for the first reformers of the Church, such as Luther, Zwingli, Farel, and others, were ordinary pastors and doctors of the Church; and therefore, by the force of their calling, they were bound to oppose the errors which they detected in the Church, just as Sacred Scripture everywhere admonisheth ordinary pastors to watch against wolves and perverse teachers (Acts 20:29-31). Likewise, to stop the mouths of those who contradict (1 Timothy 3:2; Titus 1:9,11). And not to suffer the servants of Christ to be seduced by false prophets (Revelation 2:20). Although we acknowledge that there was need of extraordinary gifts, motion, and zeal to accomplish such a work in the common corruption of the Church.

Objection: But all those were called by the Papal Church, and indeed bound by oath to propose that and no other doctrine.

Response: The Papacy itself must be distinguished from the Church over which it exercised dominion, as Paul clearly distinguisheth in 2 Thessalonians 2:4. “The son of perdition sitteth in the temple of God, as God.” For the Papacy itself is not the Church of God but an ulcer of the Church, which was to be separated from the Church; and therefore, although that hierarchy of the Pontiff bindeth all those pastors to defend the errors which the Papacy fostereth, yet the Church of God, which at that time still adhered unto the Papacy and which had also consented unto their calling, bound them to do the contrary, or rather God, who had called them unto this office even through the consent of that Church. But when a great part of that body did not admit this healing but tyrannically opposed it, then it was the duty of those pious pastors and of the people still adhering unto them to separate the sounder part from that other incurable part, as Paul admonisheth (Romans 16:17), and elsewhere.

Ames saith: Wycliffe, Luther, Zwingli, and similar first restorers of the Gospel were not, properly speaking, extraordinary ministers. Yet they are not badly called extraordinary by some:

I. For they performed something similar unto what was performed by extraordinary ministers of old.

II. For, with respect unto degree, they received certain singular gifts from God, as the thing itself required, which can also be affirmed of many among the more illustrious martyrs.

III. For, with the order of that time disturbed and collapsed, they necessarily had to attempt some things beyond the common order. It is therefore ridiculous for those men to demand miracles for the confirmation of that doctrine which they proposed, since such attestation was not necessary even in all extraordinary ministers.

Spanheim saith: Question: Whether the name of Calvinists is deservedly imputed unto the churches which are commonly called Reformed? Answer: The occasion for this question is given by the ordinary nomenclature of Calvinists, whereby our churches, more than can be said, are odiously traduced by many adversaries, as if by some conspiracy. But that this is alien both from truth and from charity, and is done beyond all reason, we will demonstrate:

I. For we do not in fact prescribe that name unto ourselves or unto our religion, but rather we remove it and deprecate it, taught by Paul that in religion we should take our name only from Him into whose name we were baptized and who was crucified for us (1 Corinthians 1:12-13; 3:4).

II. For that name cannot be prescribed unto our churches by right without singular bitterness. For we acknowledge Calvin as an eminent organ of God and a faithful servant of God, but not as the author of our religion, but [unto the] one Christ speaking in Scripture.

III. For Calvin was not even among the first promoters of the Reformation of the churches, since long before him divers heroes, measuring the temple (Revelation 11:1), applied their hand unto the purging of the Church: Luther, Melanchthon, Capito, Hedio, Bucer, and others in Germany; Zwingli, Oecolampadius, Haller in Switzerland; Peter Schevilla, Jacob Faber, William Farel, and Anthony Salonerius in France; and others elsewhere.

IV. For Calvin was not the reformer of any particular church, not even of Geneva, where he taught and spent the greater part of his life, since it is established that he went there only some years after the Gospel had been preached there and Papal idolatry expelled from that city, and was detained there by Farel beyond his intention and hope.

V. For we do not admit the doctrine delivered or expounded by Calvin as Calvin’s, either reduplicatively or as his, whether it resteth on his authority or suffrage, but as we see it either in itself conformable unto Sacred Scripture or demonstrated by Calvin from it.

VI. For we freely depart from Calvin, whether in the exposition of certain places of Scripture or in some private opinions. Nor doth any of us profess Calvin to be without error or think that he must swear unto the words of Calvin. Which is clear from the example of Theodore Beza alone, a great theologian, who oft ingenuously dissented from Calvin, his colleague and most conjoined brother.

VII. For so far is it that Calvin sought or affected such a thing or drove his disciples unto his name, that he referred his readers and hearers with John the Baptist unto the one Christ in the Prophetic and Apostolic Scripture, and wished that from it alone both the writings of others and his own be examined and judged.

VIII. For, although through Calvin and his most learned writings, unto which not even the most hostile enemies can deny the praise of erudition, eloquence, or singular judgment, many have profited greatly, and through him have come unto the knowledge of the truth, yet no one among us ever thought otherwise of Calvin than that he is to be reckoned among the faithful servants of God, through whom we believe, who plant and water, but God alone giveth the increase, nor do the gifts, labors, or success of any doctor, however excellent, give a name in religion.

IX. For innumerable believe and profess the same fundamental doctrine with Calvin, unto whom not even the name of Calvin is known, much less his writings, and so they did not believe through Calvin, so far is it that they believe because of Calvin what they believe.

X. For it is supposed, not proved, that Calvin, in those dogmas in which we follow him, delivered a new or alien doctrine from the doctrine of Christ and the Apostles. If the adversaries deny it, it must be taught, not merely said; if they concede it, they ought not to be his adversaries nor impose a denomination on our churches from the instrument of doctrine but from its author. Arguments of this kind must be opposed unto those who odiously traduce us in many places of Germany and Switzerland by the name of Zwinglians.

XX. Our Church Is the True Church

But on the contrary, our churches are deservedly affirmed to be the true churches of the Lord.

Junius saith: Because in them shine the pure preaching of the word and the administration of the sacraments as instituted by the Lord (Matthew 26:27, etc.).
