Nor only that, but also by the grace of God, we can justly glory in the Lord concerning the succession of the primitive Church both in doctrine and in persons, not indeed through individual heads, but yet in common and in the body. Moreover, true antiquity is with us: for Christ is the author of the doctrine which we profess. The time of our Church is from the beginning of the Gospel; our dogmas are drawn only from the pure fountains of Sacred Scripture. Professing these and adhering unto them are all true martyrs and faithful from the cradle of the Church. Finally, the enemies are manifest and latent heretics, but especially Antichrist, who through his troops, deceiving and deceived, opposeth himself unto the truth of God.

XXI. The Particular Church

Thus far concerning the Church in general. There followeth the particular Church, instituted and enjoying its own proper form, order, and government.

Ames saith: The Church, which acteth on earth, although it be not entirely visible at the same time, yet in its parts is visible, both separately in its singular members and also conjointly in assemblies or congregations. Congregations are as it were similar parts of the Catholic Church, and thus participate in its name and nature. Therefore, a particular Church, with respect unto that common nature which is found in all particular churches, is a species of the Church in general; but with respect unto the Catholic Church, which hath the nature of a whole, it is a member composed of the aggregation of divers singular members, and thus with respect unto them, it is also a whole. Such a particular congregation or Church is a society of the faithful joined together by a special bond for the constant exercise of the communion of saints among themselves. It is a society of the faithful because that same thing in profession constituteth the visible Church which in its internal and real nature constituteth the mystical Church, that is, faith. But since true faith hath conjoined holiness, which it effectually worketh (Acts 15:9), and thus the profession of true faith cannot be disjoined from the profession of holiness, therefore, promiscuously and in the same sense, the Church is called a society of the faithful and a society of saints (Ephesians 1:1): “To the saints which are at Ephesus, and to the faithful in Christ Jesus.” (1 Corinthians 1:2 with 2 Corinthians 1:1; Romans 1:7; Colossians 1:2). Hence, even visible and particular churches, by reason of this faith which they profess, are rightly said to be in God the Father and in the Lord Jesus Christ. It is also most probable that there is no such particular Church wherein the profession of true faith flourisheth, but that in the same there are also found some truly faithful. But those who are faithful only in profession, while they remain in that society, are members of that Church as also of the Catholic Church, only as to external state, not as to internal or essential state (1 John 2:19): “They went out from us, but they were not of us.” The children of the faithful who are in the Church are to be numbered among the faithful as members of the Church (1 Corinthians 7:14): “Your children are holy.” For they are partakers of the same covenant and also of the same profession with their parents. Nevertheless, infants are not so perfect members of the Church that they can exercise the acts of communion or be admitted to participate in all its privileges, unless first an increase of faith appeareth; but from those things which pertain unto the beginning of faith and entrance into the Church, they are not to be excluded. The faithful do not constitute a particular Church, although perchance several meet or live together in the same place, unless they are joined together by a special bond; for thus one Church would oft be dissolved into many, and many also confused into one. This bond is a covenant, either expressed or implied, whereby the faithful particularly bind themselves to perform all those duties, both toward God and toward each other, which pertain unto the nature and edification of the Church. Hence it is that in the Old Testament we so oft read of the renewal of the covenant, as oft as a solemn reformation of the Church is related. Hence, no one is rightly admitted into the Church except through the confession of faith and stipulation of obedience. This federated conjunction constituteth the Church only insofar as it regardeth the exercise of the communion of saints; for the same faithful men can join themselves by covenant to constitute a city or some civil society, which immediately regardeth the common civil good, but they do not constitute a Church unless, in their constitution, they regard holy communion with God among themselves. Hence, the same men can constitute a city or political society and not a Church, or a Church and not a city, or both a Church and a city. Hence it is that assemblies are said to be held formally ecclesiastically in the name of the Lord (Matthew 18:20; 1 Corinthians 5:4). Nor yet doth any sudden conjunction and exercise of holy communion suffice to constitute a Church, unless there also accedeth that constancy, at least as to intention, which bringeth about the state of a body and of members in a certain spiritual polity. This Church is instituted by God and Christ (Hebrews 3:4): “For every house is builded by some man; but he that built all things is God.” And in this respect, it differeth from the mystical Church, whose aggregation into one is not prescribed unto men but is immediately perfected by divine operation; but this aggregation into the instituted Church is so perfected by God that His command and man’s duty and works intervene (Hebrews 10:25): “Not forsaking the assembling of ourselves together.” For although the mystical Church, as it is in its members, is distributed only into adjuncts and subjects, in which respect we say the Belgian Church, the British, the French, just as the sea itself, according unto the shores it washeth, we say the Belgian sea, the British, the French, although it be one and the same sea; yet the instituted churches are divers most special species or individuals participating in the same common nature, just as divers fountains, divers schools, divers families; although many or all can perchance be called one Church by reason of some one affection which they have in common, just as many families of some illustrious stock are oft designated by the name of one family, as the Nassau family, etc.

XXII. The Government and Discipline of the Church

For the Church hath its own singular government and discipline.

Calvin saith: Let us observe that there is a twofold government in man: one spiritual, whereby the conscience is instructed unto piety and the worship of God; the other political, whereby man is educated unto the duties of humanity and civility which are to be observed among men. They are commonly called spiritual and temporal jurisdiction, not improper names, whereby it is signified that the former species of government pertaineth unto the life of the soul, but the latter is engaged in those things which are of the present life: not only in feeding or clothing but in prescribing laws whereby man may live holily, honestly, and modestly among men. For the former hath its seat in the inner mind; the latter only regulateth external manners. The one we may call the spiritual kingdom, the other the political kingdom.

Geneva saith: Although these things be so, yet because some, deceived by a false appearance of liberty, others deterred by the asperity of certain severer natures, reject this discipline as a human invention, we will prove that it was instituted by God and approved by Christ and the Apostles. And first, indeed, concerning laws, the first part of that discipline, there is no or certainly very little controversy. For all will easily concede what is most evident, that God, who willeth that His Church be governed by His own, not another’s, arbitration, hath prescribed laws for it: dogmatic, moral, and ecclesiastical. Nevertheless, some move controversies concerning the prefects of ecclesiastical discipline, and especially whether they have the power of jurisdiction. But from the books of Moses, it appeareth that just as Moses himself with the seventy elders exercised the parts of civil magistracy, so Aaron with his ministers, priests, and Levites, presided over ecclesiastical things. And besides these, there were also in the Jewish people those whom they called “heads of the fathers,” whom, since Scripture oft joineth with those who functioned in a public office in the Church, it is likely that they were also part of the ecclesiastical synedrium: not that they were permitted to perform sacred rites like the priests and Levites, but because there were always certain things to be done in the Church which regarded the external polity of the Church, in the execution of which the priests used their work and counsel. It is established, therefore, that in the Jewish Church there were rectors constituted for this ecclesiastical order. But that the cognition of ecclesiastical things pertained unto them can be proved. For the judgment of leprosy was ecclesiastical and was to be passed by the priests, as Moses teacheth (Leviticus 14:36; Deuteronomy 24:8), and this is confirmed by the words of Christ: “Go, show thyself to the priest” (Luke 5:14). But much more clearly and distinctly it is treated in 2 Chronicles 19:8. For after the history relateth that King Jehoshaphat restored the political order, it addeth what he also performed in the restoration of the Church. “Moreover in Jerusalem did Jehoshaphat set of the Levites, and of the priests, and of the chief of the fathers of Israel, for the judgment of the Lord.” And verse 11: “Behold, Amariah the chief priest is over you in all matters of the Lord; and Zebadiah the son of Ishmael, the ruler of the house of Judah, for all the king’s matters.” Their power is treated in the same place: “And whatsoever cause shall come,” etc. And this power of theirs extended even unto excommunication, as is demonstrated by so many laws concerning sacrifices to be offered for divers kinds of sins, which occur everywhere in Leviticus and elsewhere. For expiation presupposeth that uncleanness which was followed by exclusion from the altar until purification and confession before the priest, that is, suitable testimony of repentance. Such, therefore, was the discipline formerly constituted in the Jewish people, but not always observed. For sometimes the politicians inserted themselves into the office of the ecclesiastics, and vice versa, as it is established to have happened around the time of Christ from the evangelical history. So that to argue from any examples is dangerous. But Christ, not at all approving that abuse of the synagogue but restoring the lawful use of this discipline in the Church, commandeth (Matthew 18:17) that he who despiseth the public admonitions of the Church be regarded as a heathen and a publican. But that this may be done legitimately, it is necessary that the rebellious and contumacious one be declared such unto the people by a sentence passed by the senate, which representeth the Church and administereth its right, yea that of Christ Himself, the head of the Church.

XXIII. The Power of the Church

It hath power, but spiritual, and in ministering, not in dominating.

Junius saith: Ministry, from ministrare (to serve), is generally taken for that action and work of another whereby, as by a means, we use to achieve something; whence afterward, kat’ exochēn, it is restricted unto the government of the Church: either spiritual, which regardeth the spirit, or corporal, which regardeth only the body (of which also I. Presbyterial, II. Diaconal is said, according unto the persons administering): because God useth this as a serving means to gather His elect and to rule them. We here take the name of ministry spiritually, for the spiritual and presbyterial (since it far excelleth the others), that is, for the ministry of those whom Paul saith (1 Timothy 5:17) are worthy of double honor, who labor in the word and doctrine, distinguishing them from those presbyters who have only the care of discipline and order. It is clear that the Church hath not absolute power to hand down anything at its own discretion, but is subject unto Christ, that is, unto His word and doctrine: so that whatever power the Church hath, it is circumscribed by certain and definite limits. We certainly hear and honor the Church as a perpetual teacher: as a mother, nurse, tutress, we reverence her: we confess that there is no other ordinary entrance into life except that she conceiveth us, beareth us, nourisheth us, governeth us, as long as we remain in this world.

Geneva saith: Two things are chiefly to be observed: one, that this whole power is spiritual, that is, it directly regardeth the conscience; and therefore, it differeth from the power and authority of magistrates in specific form and proper end. The other, that it is not autokratorikē, nor placed in the discretion of those unto whom it is attributed, but only hypēretikē, or administrative, defined by certain ends and laws prescribed by the one God, Lord, and Lawgiver, from whom alone its force and efficacy depend. Therefore, all domination which both the Roman Pontiff and the other pseudo-bishops, attributing unto themselves, have also arrogated temporal power, as they call it; and, what is even more intolerable, have usurped the right over consciences, is not power from God but tyranny devised by Satan to disturb human society and to undermine the Church.

Ames saith: The Church itself cannot properly make new laws for itself concerning new things to be instituted, but should only take care to inquire well into the will of Christ and to observe His institutions in order and decency, with the greatest fruit of edification. Ministry is an ecclesiastical function whereby a man chosen dispenseth sacred things by special right (1 Corinthians 4:1; 2 Corinthians 4:1). It is called ministry because that power which is committed unto ecclesiastical men is only the power of acting by the command of Christ and by mere obedience toward Him (1 Corinthians 4:1-2). Spiritual power of command or royal power, whereby one acteth from his own liberty and discretion, is not of men but of Christ alone. Hence, the minister of the Church is bound to execute his office through himself, as one who hath not the power to delegate a vicar in his place; for this would not be of obedience but of command. Therefore, a perpetual minister of divers churches to be cared for necessarily through vicars is not by God’s institution but by human ambition and presumption. The power is not absolute but relative, that is, it consisteth not in an absolute faculty of doing something but in the right whereby one hath the power of acting rightly and legitimately what he could not do before, and therefore it is called the power of right. But it is of special right because it regardeth certain special offices unlawful unto others and investeth certain common offices in a special manner. From the ministry ariseth the third state of the Church. For as by faith it hath its essential state, and by combination its integral state, so also by the ministry it hath a certain organic state, since it is now made fit to exercise all those operations which pertain unto the good of the whole. The reason and direction of these operations is ecclesiastical polity. The form of this polity is plainly monarchical with respect unto Christ the head and king; but with respect unto visible and vicarious administration, it is of a mixed nature, partly as it were aristocratic and partly as it were democratic. Hence, in the legitimate ministry of the Church, there is no place for hierarchy but rather for hierodulia. Therefore, one minister is not subject, in his dispensation, unto the power of another, but all immediately depend on Christ, just as those angels who are inferior in function are immediately subject unto God, not unto other angels.

XXIV. The Necessity of Calling in the Ecclesiastical Ministry

In the ecclesiastical ministry, calling and office are to be considered; and first, indeed, here a calling is necessarily required.

Ames saith: Calling is the action whereby, with the authority of ministering, the office is committed unto someone. Therefore, those are altogether ridiculous who so institute the calling of ministers that they grant them not the power of preaching the word except by some new concession. A necessary adjunct of calling is aptitude for the ministry. Hence, those who are altogether unfit to fulfill the ministry, if they are called unto it by men, are ministers of men, not of God (Hosea 4:6). This aptitude ariseth from a suitable measure of gifts and a ready will to undertake and execute that office.

Professor saith: For just as it is the Lord’s to send His laborers into His vineyard (Matthew 9:38), so no one of His faithful laborers taketh this honor unto himself, but he who is called by God. Which the Apostle proveth by the example of Aaron (Hebrews 5:4), and by this question he hinteth: “How shall they preach, except they be sent?” (Romans 10:15). Concerning false prophets, God pronounceth on the contrary: “I have not sent these prophets, yet they ran” (Jeremiah 23:21). Against the Socinians, who deny that any singular manner of sending is required to undertake the sacred ministry, we object these places. They answer that the Apostle in Hebrews 5:4 speaketh only of the Aaronic priesthood, wherein formerly there was more honor than labor; but in the present ecclesiastical ministry, there is more labor than honor, nor do such ministers take or arrogate unto themselves, being fit to teach, since they have the gift of teaching others, the right of desiring and undertaking it. In the Socinian Catechism of Racow, Chapter 2, concerning the government and governance of the Church of Christ; Socinus in his treatise On the Church; Theophilus Nicolaides in his defense of Socinus’s treatise On the Church, Chapter 1. This is a false exception of the Socinians unto the place in Hebrews 5. For although the Apostle there, generally speaking of the priesthood, illustrateth this his axiom, “No man taketh this honor unto himself, but he that is called of God,” by the example of Aaron, yet since he describeth the priesthood from the effects of the sacred ecclesiastical ministry, and by the rule of logicians, the judgment is the same concerning similar things, it necessarily followeth that the Apostle’s general axiom, by reason of the ecclesiastical ministry, of which there are divers species, can be accommodated in the same way unto other ecclesiastical ministers, of whatever order they be, as it is particularly applied by the Apostle unto Aaron, since no dissimilar example can be brought from the sacred letters of any of the prophets, or of the Apostles and Evangelists, or of other ecclesiastical ministers approved by God. For none of them is read to have taken upon himself the dignity of the ecclesiastical office without God’s calling. Moreover, the leitourgia of the Aaronic priest, whereby he performed the sacred things of which the Apostle maketh mention there, both in his own name and in the name of the people, was of no less labor than honor, and therefore honor is synecdochically named by the Apostle, because for that leitourgia he was worthy of double honor, as the Apostle also affirmeth concerning the presbyters of the New Testament (1 Timothy 5:17). Nor doth the Apostle attribute more or less, but only as much labor as honor unto the work of the sacred ministry, when he calleth it a good work (1 Timothy 3:1). And although the desire of the episcopate, as the Apostle teacheth there, is praiseworthy, yet the ambition of those is to be blamed who, without waiting for God’s sending or the Church’s approval, undertake that office by their own judgment and private arbitration.

XXV. Ordinary and Extraordinary Calling

As the ministry, so the calling is either ordinary or extraordinary.

Walaeus saith: But calling is twofold: extraordinary and ordinary. Extraordinary is that whereby God sent the prophets and Apostles and, without the intervention of men, dispatched them to preach, as is clear from the example of all the prophets and Apostles, and especially of the Apostle Paul (Galatians 1:1). See also Luke 6:13. The properties of this extraordinary calling are that in the doctrine which they proposed, they could not err (John 16:13), that they were generally furnished with the gift of miracles to demonstrate the truth of their mission, or at least with such efficacy and evidence of doctrine that the consciences of all the pious were convinced of it.

Question: Here it is asked whether in extraordinary calling miracles are necessary?

Response: 1. For the most part, we see that it was done. 2. In others, we see something analogous unto miracles whereby it could be established, as in the Old Testament there was Urim and Thummim (Jeremiah 26:19), the truth of predictions conspiring with the truth of doctrine, as is seen in Deuteronomy 13:1-3; 18:22. Likewise, prediction concerning them or their miraculous birth, as we see in Samson and John the Baptist.

Ordinary calling is that whereby Christ sendeth pastors, but through the ministry of men, such as the calling of all ordinary ministers in the Church.

Ames saith: Ministry is either extraordinary or ordinary. Extraordinary is that which hath a certain higher and more perfect direction than can be had by ordinary means. Hence, such ministers always have extraordinary gifts and assistance, so that they minister without error. The right of extraordinary ministers is conferred not by man nor through man properly, but by God alone through Jesus Christ and the Holy Spirit (Galatians 1:1). Hence, the calling unto such ministry is immediate. Nevertheless, not every extraordinary calling is so immediate as to exclude all ministry of men, as appeareth in the calling of Elisha and Matthias, but it excludeth only that ministry which is destitute of infallible direction. This extraordinary ministry was plainly necessary for the Church because that will of God which pertaineth unto living well unto God could not be investigated by human industry and ordinary means, as all other arts and sciences, but required men raised up and sent by God, unto whom He revealed His will, that they might be unto us in place of God Himself (Exodus 4:15-16): “Thou shalt be to him instead of God.” Unto these extraordinary ministers, God revealed His will:

I. By a living voice (Revelation 1:10), unto which oft was added the appearance and address of an angel or of Christ Himself, as the Angel of the Covenant.

II. By vision, whereby, together with the word, the species of things to be indicated were represented unto the eyes of the watchful.

III. By dream, whereby similar things were proposed unto the minds of the sleeping.

IV. Sometimes also by a certain singular familiarity, as it were, face to face, without enigmas (Numbers 12:6-8): “If there be a prophet among you, I the Lord will make myself known unto him in a vision, and will speak unto him in a dream. My servant Moses is not so, who is faithful in all mine house. With him will I speak mouth to mouth, even apparently, and not in dark speeches; and the similitude of the Lord shall he behold.”

The mode of this revelation was so powerful that it oft rapt men into ecstasy, whereby they were so seized above themselves that they perceived nothing besides what was proposed, nor even that entirely according unto all its circumstances (2 Corinthians 12:3-4). Yet it is so certain that its divine truth is always confirmed and sealed in a singular way unto those unto whom it is revealed, so that it needeth not other confirmation (Galatians 1:17; 2:6): “Neither went I up to Jerusalem to them which were apostles before me... But of these who seemed to be somewhat, (whatsoever they were, it maketh no matter to me: God accepteth no man’s person:) for they who seemed to be somewhat in conference added nothing to me.” Although sometimes also, abundantly, miracles are added (Judges 6:36-38). This extraordinary ministry is either for the first institution of the Church, or for the singular and extraordinary conservation of the instituted Church, or finally for the extraordinary restoration of the collapsed Church. The ministry of institution always hath the testimony of miracles conjoined (Hebrews 2:3-4). Yet miracles do not so attest any doctrine that they immediately make faith in it. For that doctrine which consenteth not with the known will of God ought not to be admitted, although it seemeth to be confirmed by miracles (Deuteronomy 13:1-3): “If there arise among you a prophet, or a dreamer of dreams, and giveth thee a sign or a wonder, and the sign or the wonder come to pass, whereof he spake unto thee, saying, Let us go after other gods, which thou hast not known, and let us serve them; thou shalt not hearken unto the words of that prophet,” etc. (Galatians 1:8). The ministry of conservation and restoration, although it be extraordinary and oft confirmed by miracles, yet doth not always or necessarily require the testimony of miracles, as appeareth in many in the Old Testament and in John the Baptist. Extraordinary ministers were the prophets, Apostles, and Evangelists.

Spanheim saith: The Apostles were extraordinary ministers who were employed for the gathering of the Church and were furnished partly with immediate calling, partly with prophetic light, partly with the infallible direction of the Holy Spirit, partly with the gifts of miracles, partly with universal inspection over all churches, and thus with extraordinary authority (Matthew 10; 28; Galatians 1:1; Ephesians 4:11, etc.). The Apostolic men were: 1. Prophets. 2. Evangelists. 3. The seventy disciples. Prophets, who by the extraordinary inspiration of the Holy Spirit had both the knowledge of divers secret things and a singular faculty of interpreting the Scriptures and the gift of using them in divers tongues for the edification of the nascent Christian Church (1 Corinthians 12:9-10; Ephesians 4:11). Evangelists were Apostolic men who either, besides the Apostles, applied their hand unto writing the Gospels by divine inspiration and guidance, or performed vicarious work for the Apostles either in constituting or in governing the churches, such as Silas, Timothy, Titus, and others. The disciples can be reckoned among extraordinary ministers who were employed by Christ for the preparation and inchoation of His kingdom in Israel (Luke 10:1, etc.).

XXVI. The Ordinary Calling of Ministers

The ordinary calling of the ministry is performed by the Church and consisteth in election and confirmation.

Professor saith: Unto the legitimate calling of ordinary pastors, two means chiefly are to be employed: the election of those to be called and the ordination of those elected. The right of electing pastors belongeth unto the Church, and thus is common unto the people with the presbyters; the right of ordaining them is proper unto the presbytery alone. Therefore, the election of pastors formerly was done by the acclamations and acclamation of the whole people, which, having heard the name of the pastor to be elected, indicated their suffrage consentaneous with the suffrage of the presbytery by hands uplifted (Acts 14:23). But ordination, which today is called confirmation, was done by some one of the pastors in the name of the whole presbytery, before the face of the Church, by the imposition of hands (1 Timothy 5:22). That right of electing pastors, and by their suffrage either approving or disapproving the judgment of the presbytery concerning the pastors to be elected, the primitive Church retained for some time from the age of the Apostles, as is evident from this testimony of Cyprian, Book 1, Epistle 4: “The people chiefly hath the power either of electing worthy priests or of refusing unworthy ones.” And Epistle 68: “We see that it descendeth from divine authority that a priest be chosen in the presence of the people under the eyes of all, and be approved worthy and fit by public judgment and testimony.” Therefore, Augustine, after he had chosen Eradius as his successor, besought his Church that they would receive him unto the episcopate. But lest in the election of a bishop some error pernicious unto the whole Church be committed, pious antiquity was wont:

  1. By a solemn examination to explore first his doctrine and life, and if anywhere it was destitute of fit judges, to summon presbyters from neighboring churches unto that end, according unto the canon of the Apostle (2 Timothy 2:2): “Commit thou these things unto faithful men, who shall be fit also to teach others.”
  2. His name, where it was permitted, was wont to be proposed publicly unto all, written upon a tablet; but where it was not permitted, it was wont to be read openly in the ecclesiastical assembly, so that if any vice, disgrace, or scandal had been found in him, it might be brought within a day prefixed unto the presbytery. By which circumspection it was provided that no one be admitted unto the sacred ministry unless he also had good testimony from those without, according unto the admonition of the Apostle (1 Timothy 3:7). For when the deacon proclaimed in the Church, it was permitted unto all to object against the pastor to be ordained the access unto the government of souls if he had ever committed any crime, as Origen teacheth against Celsus, Book 8, near the end. Both rites of pious antiquity are always to be imitated by us, so that from suitable and universal testimony of the domestics of the faith, it may be well established unto the whole people that the pastor of the Church, elected and ordained with their suffrage acceding, is blameless and apt to feed the sheep of Christ. Nor only in the ordinations of bishops and presbyters but also of deacons are both rites to be imitated by us, as Cyprian admonisheth, Epistle 68.

Polanus saith: Unto the legitimate election of ministers of the Church, especially of pastors, is required the free and ingenuous consent and suffrage of the whole Church concerned, that is, of the presbyters and of the flock, not sold by entreaty nor by price, much less coerced and extorted: so that it is for the whole Church to choose ministers for itself, as the following arguments prove:

  1. For even in the time of the Apostles, the whole Church concerned chose ministers for itself; nor did the Apostles themselves appoint anyone unto ecclesiastical offices by their authority alone, but always with the Church consenting and approving (Acts 6:2and following; Acts 14:23).
  2. For thus the liberty of the Church is preserved, which Christ gave unto it. For neither is a pastor or minister of the word of God to be obtruded upon the unwilling Church. Canon: “No one against his will,” Distinction 61.
  3. For this maketh that the minister may preside over the Lord’s flock with a good conscience, from whom he is elected; and that the Lord’s flock in turn may more easily present itself to be taught and fed by him than by one who is intruded against its will. Nor yet shall the political magistrate act in the election of ministers of the Church according unto his own discretion, but shall commit the business unto the ministers of the Church, as did the pious Emperor Valentinian, of whom Theodoret speaketh, Ecclesiastical History, Book 4, Chapters 5-6.

Walaeus saith: We say that the election or designation of a minister pertaineth not unto the supreme magistrate alone, as Grotius and others have judged; nor also unto the Church alone, excluding the magistrate, as others will, especially the Anabaptists and Papists; but we say that this election pertaineth unto the whole Church with a certain respect, yet with due order observed, so that the prefects of the churches go before, and the people assent, each in their order. But unto the supreme magistrate we attribute:

  1. First, the care and inspection that the election be instituted according unto the word of God, because the magistrate is the guardian of both tables, and thus also of the fourth commandment.
  2. Then, we attribute unto every Christian magistrate, even subordinate, suffrage and consent, as unto a part of the Church, and indeed not the least. Yet we deny that absolute authority belongeth unto them which some will attribute unto them, but judge that it pertaineth more unto the prefects of the Church with the consent of the Church. We confirm this by these reasons:
  3. For it was before demonstrated that the examination of doctrine and morals, likewise the confirmation by imposition of hands, pertain unto them. Therefore, the election also pertaineth chiefly unto them, because these cannot be done without discretion and judgment concerning the persons themselves.
  4. It is demonstrated from the practice of the Old Testament. For Aaron with his sons is consecrated by Moses, by the command of God, and that as a prophet and ambassador of God, with the consent of all the rulers of the people and of the whole people (Exodus 29:4; 40:12). And Zadok by Nathan in the assemblies of the whole kingdom (1 Chronicles 29:22). Jeroboam and the whole people with him are reproved because they acted otherwise (1 Kings 13:34; 2 Chronicles 13:9).
  5. Pastors ought to have testimony from all (1 Timothy 3:7). Therefore, they ought to be elected with the knowledge and consent of all.
  6. From the practice of the New Testament. For Christ, not as a magistrate but as our Prophet, sent His disciples (John 20:21): “As the Father hath sent me, even so send I you.” The Apostles followed the same with the consent of the Church, and that either by themselves or by their disciples (Acts 1:24; 6:3; 14:23), where the word cheirotonein is used, and that with prayers and fastings of the whole Church; for although that word is also taken for any election, as in Acts 10:41, yet where the propriety of the word can be preserved, it is altogether to be preserved; and the circumstance of the place requireth that it be so done, since they did this through all the churches with fasting and prayers.
  7. Pastors are bound to watch against wolves and perverse teachers (Acts 20:29), also to cast them out of the Church and not to suffer them to teach (Revelation 2:2, etc.); therefore, they ought also to watch that they enter not.
  8. Finally, the practice of the ancient Christian Church also showeth this. It is clear from the Canons of the Apostles, where at least three bishops are required for this. Then, in the Synod of Nicaea, the bishops of the province must convene and elect with the consent of the people. So in the Synod of Constantinople. Yea, this endured until the times of Charlemagne, in whose laws the clergy, the honored among the people, and the people are expressly conjoined.

Exception: But this election of ministers by the Apostles was only extraordinary until there were Christian magistrates, when that care was wholly devolved unto them.

Response:

  1. This exception is feigned and nowhere delivered in the Scriptures.
  2. The whole ancient Church, not only before the times of Constantine but also afterward, preserved that power and order.
  3. If this were true, the Church, when it receiveth Christian magistrates, ought to seek from them the confirmation of its pastors previously elected, as other officers of the kingdom are wont. But this is unheard of in the churches which emerge from the cross.
  4. Even in the Old Testament, they had this power, which was to be preserved by the king, by the priests, and by the people.

Objection: But Moses (Exodus 40:12) chose Aaron with his sons as priest. But Moses was not a priest but the political prefect of the people.

Response:

  1. It is false that Moses chose Aaron and his sons as priest; for God chose them, and through Moses (as we said before) confirmed them in the priesthood, and that in the presence of the whole people.
  2. Nor did Moses confirm them as a political prefect but as a prophet of God and an extraordinary priest, which is proved by invincible reasons:
    1. For he handled those holy garments, also the Urim and Thummim, which he put on Aaron and his sons, which it was never lawful for any king to handle.
    2. For Moses, in that consecration, offered sacrifices for Aaron and his sons, and that by the command of God (Exodus 29:10).

Second Objection: But Solomon, who was king and not a priest, deposed Abiathar the high priest from the priesthood and substituted Zadok, as is read in 1 Kings 2:26.

Response: Some answer that Solomon did this as a prophet. But this answer cannot be sufficiently proved from the circumstances of the text itself. Therefore, let us concede that Solomon did this as king; we say that this was a political punishment for political causes, not ecclesiastical: for Abiathar had conspired against Solomon with Adonijah and Joab to cast Solomon from the throne. None of us ever denied that pastors, for such causes, can be afflicted with such punishments by the magistrate.

Objection: But Solomon not only deposed Abiathar but also substituted Zadok.

Response: I deny that Solomon did this by his own royal authority, because, with Abiathar removed, the law of God itself substituted Zadok as priest, since Zadok was second to the high priest and indeed from the family of Eleazar, unto whom by divine law the high priesthood was due, as we have more broadly demonstrated in our writing On the Authority of the Magistrate. Therefore, Solomon here was the guardian and executor of the divine law, just as all the doctors of the Reformed Church acknowledge that the magistrate is the guardian not only of the second table but also of the first, and therefore ought also to take care that legitimate ministers be appointed unto the churches, but according unto the order instituted by Christ. Then, this also is to be noted, that Solomon did this not by his sole authority but in the assemblies of the whole kingdom, among whom were also the chief priests and the prefects of the people, as is expressly affirmed in 1 Chronicles 29:22.

XXVII. The Holiness of the Minister

Moreover, he is to be elected holily who commendeth himself by life and doctrine.

Polanus saith: Nor indeed ought anyone eagerly to seek and ambition the ecclesiastical office, especially the pastorate or episcopate: as neither Aaron, nor any of the prophets, nor the Apostles, nor the bishops appointed by the Apostles, nor other pious bishops, such as Ambrose and Augustine, eagerly sought or ambitioned the episcopate. Nor is there anything that anyone may object from that of Paul (1 Timothy 3:1): “Faithful is this saying, If a man desire the office of a bishop, he desireth a good work.” For Paul doth not say that he who willeth, or who thinketh himself to be excellently learned and fit, desireth the episcopate. He did not command, did not enjoin, did not sanction by law, did not exhort those nourishing in themselves a desire for the episcopate to desire it. But since he noteth that there are many who are seized with a desire for excelling and dominating in the Church, as it were with a certain drunkenness, and are least endowed with those virtues with which a bishop ought to be adorned, and perceive not the labors, sweats, struggles, dangers, cares, and watchings of the episcopate, but, without weighing their own strengths or considering the magnitude of the function, leap unto the episcopate, he wished to teach by these words that the episcopate is an arduous business: it is work, not play; care, not luxury; an office subject to rendering accounts, not a dominion free and immune from all censure; a paternal stewardship, not a tyrannical license. But he taught this to the end that, repressing the dangerous impetus of ambitious men, he might warn them not rashly to undertake an office which exceedeth the capacity and ability of most. See the explanation of this passage of Paul in Book 3 of the Epistles of Isidore of Pelusium, Epistle 226. Much less ought anyone to buy the ecclesiastical function for himself with a price (Acts 8:18), or to invade it by force. Yea, neither ought bishops nor the Church to sell it unto anyone for money (Acts 8:20). The examination is twofold, of life and of doctrine.

Whosoever attempteth either by craft to creep in or by force to break into ecclesiastical functions are to be kept from them: for he that entereth not by the door into the sheepfold but climbeth up some other way, the same is a thief and a robber (John 10:1). Blessed Ambrose, in the ministers of the Church, observed even the external gestures of the body, and if they were indecent, for that reason either did not admit them unto the ministry of the Church or excluded those previously admitted. He testifieth this in Book 1 of Offices, Chapter 18: “Ye remember, my sons, a certain friend who, when he seemed to commend himself by diligent offices, yet for this alone was not received by me into the clergy, that his gestures were greatly unbecoming.”

XXVIII. Ordinary Ministers

Ordinary ministers are presbyters, either teaching and ruling or ruling only, and deacons, who have the care of the poor.

Spanheim saith: Ordinary functions in the Church are those which are destined not only for a time but ordinarily for the Church, whether to be instituted and ruled at the same time or only to be ruled, unto the end of the world. But those ordinary functions are:

  1. Of pastors.
  2. Of presbyters, contradistinguished from pastors.
  3. Of deacons.

Pastors are those who are called partly to institute, partly to rule the Christian Church, and unto whom the administration both of doctrine and of the sacraments, its appendages, and of discipline is committed conjointly (Ephesians 4:11-12). These Scripture calleth promiscuously episkopoi, poimenes, hēgoumenoi, presbyteroi, diakonoi, leitourgoi, oikonomoi (Acts 20:28; 1 Thessalonians 5:12; Hebrews 13:7; Ephesians 4:11; Acts 20:17; 2 Timothy 2:14; Romans 15:16; Colossians 1:7; 1 Corinthians 4:1).

Presbyters, contradistinguished from pastors, are those who are occupied not with instituting but only with ruling the Church, and are employed not for doctrine or its appendages but only for discipline, to be administered with the pastors subsidiarily, partly to prevent, partly to detect, partly to coerce scandals, and destined for procuring ecclesiastical order (1 Corinthians 12:28; 1 Timothy 5:17). These presbyters called unto the ecclesiastical office we deem to be improperly called laymen.

Deacons are ministers destined for collecting, constituting, distributing the sacred treasury, and for the care of the poor and infirm, and called by the Church unto that office (Acts 6:2-3, etc.). Unto whom in the primitive Church were numbered deaconesses (1 Timothy 5:9).

It would be better that the functions of these presbyters and deacons be perpetual than temporary, by the example of the Apostolic Church; yet the necessary substitution of some for others ought not to be petulantly and impudently traduced, since that which is essential unto this office remaineth safe, for the office of such is not to be measured from duration but from the substance of administration.

Walaeus saith: The word “presbyter” properly denoteth an elder, as the Hebrew “zaken,” and that either of age or of dignity. Of age, as in 1 Peter 5:5, where he commandeth that the younger be subject unto the elder. Of dignity, either political, as they are often called the elders of the people (Matthew 26:59; 2 Chronicles 19:8), or ecclesiastical. Concerning the ecclesiastical elders, we must properly treat, whom Scripture calleth presbyters, because for the most part, those more advanced in age were promoted unto these offices, as in 1 Peter 5:1 and 1 Timothy 5:17, because he opposeth them unto the younger. Of these elders, our churches establish two kinds: namely, those ruling only, who are also called kybernēseis (1 Corinthians 12:28), and proistamenoi (1 Timothy 5:17), and those ruling and at the same time teaching, whom the Apostle distinctly calleth pastors and teachers (Ephesians 4:11). These latter all Christian churches acknowledge with us. Concerning the former, it is controverted whether there be in the Church such elders ordained by the Apostles who, together with the pastors, preside over the discipline of the Church and govern it. They call them lay presbyters invidiously, for they cannot be called laymen who are designated for an ecclesiastical office. We do not here dispute concerning that circumstance which some are wont to reprove, namely, that they are of annual or biennial ministry, because this is accidental, arising from churches under the cross, that the danger and labor may be lessened, since they serve without stipends because of the poverty of the churches; yet they are perpetuated in their time, and in some places always. But to the matter. It is asked properly whether there be place in the Church for such rulers. Many who patronize the episcopate deny this: Bilson, Downham, others; also the Papists are infected with it. Therefore, we must treat of this matter a little more accurately:

I. First, the place is brought forth by us from the custom of the Old Testament, unto which Christ hath respect and which He transferreth unto the Christian Church (Matthew 18). All who have written concerning the constitution of the Israelite Church acknowledge that in that Church, selected men from the other tribes sat with the priests, as is seen in2 Chronicles 19:8; Matthew 26:59, where the priests and the elders of the people convene, among whom was Joseph of Arimathea, who consented not unto the death of Christ, although he was present at their assembly. But this was not ceremonial nor properly political; therefore, it is not alien that this also be done in the Church of the New Testament.

II. Second, the very place Matthew 18:17is brought forth: “Tell it unto the church.” It is presupposed that here it treateth not of the political magistrate, because the word “church” is never used by Matthew for the political magistrate:

  1. For brethren ought not to institute complaints against brethren before Gentile magistrates (1 Corinthians 6:1). And indeed, for three hundred years, there was to be no magistrate.
  2. For the clause repugneth: “Let him be unto thee as an heathen man,” etc., and “Verily I say unto you,” which agreeth with what is written in Matthew 16:19 concerning Peter and the other Apostles.
  3. For here it is commanded that they tell it unto the church; but never in private offenses is it commanded that the magistrate be approached. But the word “church” here, with respect had unto the sanhedrins and synagogues, is used; where this order was that there be prefects of both kinds, namely, priests and elders of the people, as we have now seen in 2 Chronicles 19:8; Matthew 26:59; Acts 13:15. Which reason also proveth: for it cannot be understood of one bishop or one pastor, who are not the church.

III. Third, from the Apostolic practice in the Acts of the Apostles, both elsewhere and at Jerusalem, as we see in Acts 6:3 in the election of deacons. The twelve, calling the multitude together, said, “Look ye out among you seven men,” whom we may appoint over this business. So Acts 15:4: the apostles, elders, and brethren convene, by whom Paul and Barnabas were received; and verse 6: the apostles and elders came together for to consider of this matter.

IV. The fourth place is1 Corinthians 5:4: “When ye are gathered together, and my spirit, with the power of our Lord Jesus Christ.” And2 Corinthians 2:6: “Sufficient to such a man is this punishment, which was inflicted of many,” that on the contrary part ye ought rather to forgive him. Where mention is made of their assembly and judgment, and expressly “the many” are called, and they are said to have deliberated concerning the incestuous person to be excommunicated, and to have punished him who was to be excommunicated: which could not be done by the whole multitude, although it could be done with its consent; therefore, it is necessary that others presided here. So 1 Corinthians 14:29: he maketh mention of certain prophets and commandeth that one prophesy after another, and the rest sit by and judge; and expressly distinguisheth them from the unlearned and unbelievers who might enter into their assembly; this could not be done without some rule and authority. Romans 12:7 expressly distinguisheth proistamenoi from prophets, teachers, and deacons: “He that teacheth, in teaching; he that exhorteth, in exhortation; he that giveth, let him do it with simplicity; he that ruleth, with diligence; he that showeth mercy, with cheerfulness.” And 1 Corinthians 12:28 distinguisheth from apostles, prophets, and teachers also kybernēseis: “And God hath set some in the church, first apostles, secondarily prophets, thirdly teachers, after that miracles, then gifts of healings, helps, governments, diversities of tongues.” For that these were distinct functions and to endure perpetually in the Church is established from this, that mention is expressly made here of callings and gifts by which the body of Christ was always to be quickened and fitted together. That there were also distinct callings and gifts in divers persons is proved from this:

  1. For he proposeth these disjunctively: “first,” “secondly,” “then,” “after that.”
  2. For it would be absurd in the same oration to enumerate persons and in the same series to place gifts which could not fall upon distinct persons.
  3. And from this it is demonstrated that he compareth them with divers members and functions of members.

V. The fifth argument we draw from the perspicuous place1 Timothy 5:17: “Let the elders that rule well be counted worthy of double honor, especially they who labor in the word and doctrine.” This place greatly presseth the adversaries and alone sufficeth to demonstrate what we will, and therefore they also devise many exceptions whereby they obscure the clear truth which at first sight presenteth itself unto the minds.

Exception: Others, who see these inconveniences, seek hiding places in the word kopiōntes, as if those presbyters who labor more than the rest and are wearied in the exercise of their function are opposed unto those who act more remissly, and these are judged worthy of the greatest honor.

Response:

  1. By the word kopiōntesis indicated not some extraordinary labor but the proper labor of ministers: for kopos is common labor, but mochthos is extraordinary unto weariness. So Romans 16:12: he saluteth Tryphena and Tryphosa, “which labor in the Lord,” and elsewhere passim; see Acts 20:35: “So laboring,” etc. 1 Thessalonians 5:12: “Know them which labor among you.”
  2. It is absurd to will that Paul say that those rule well who act more remissly, or that they are worthy of double honor; since elsewhere he affirmeth that they are to be noted, and Scripture pronounceth woe unto those who are not diligent in their office, asJeremiah 48:10; 1 Corinthians 9:16.
  3. They will that bishops who do not labor in the word but only preside and rule, and rarely preach, are much more worthy of honor than those who labor in the word, against the Apostle.

VI. Sixth, the testimonies of the ancients demonstrate the same, as of Tertullian in Apologeticus, Chapter 39; of Ambrose on1 Timothy 5:1; of Epiphanius:

  1. Tertullian, in Apologeticus against the Gentiles, Chapter 39, describing the ecclesiastical assemblies of the Christians, saith: “There also are made exhortations, rebukes, and divine censure; for judgment is passed with great weight, as among those certain of God’s presence, and it is the greatest prejudgment of future judgment if anyone hath so offended that he be removed from the communion of prayer and assembly and all holy commerce. The approved elders preside, having obtained that honor not by price but by testimony.”
  2. The testimony is of Ambrose on 1 Timothy 5:1, on these words: “Rebuke not an elder,” etc. “Among all nations,” he saith, “old age is honorable; whence also the synagogue and afterward the Church had elders, without whose counsel nothing was done in the Church; which by what negligence hath become obsolete, I know not, unless perhaps by the sloth of teachers or rather by their pride, while they alone will seem something.”
  3. The place of Epiphanius proveth the same, which is in Volume 2 of the works of Jerome, where he relateth that he entered an oratory or temple in a certain village called Anablatha and there found a veil hung up on which was depicted the image of Christ or of some saint, and prayed that the presbyters of that place should thenceforth command that in the Church of Christ such veils, which are against our religion, should not be hung up. Behold, many presbyters in one village, unto whom Epiphanius imposeth this care, who doubtless in so small a place were not many pastors.

The institution of deacons is in Acts 6:2, etc., and their offices are distinguished in Romans 12:8, namely, distribution and mercy: of which the former regardeth relief through alms, the latter consolation and spiritual relief. That the office of deacons is perpetual is proved from the rules which the Apostle prescribeth concerning their election (1 Timothy 3:8). Unto this pertaineth the office of deaconesses, who ministered unto the sick, strangers, and poor women, concerning which 1 Timothy 5:9: “Let not a widow be taken into the number under threescore years old, having been the wife of one man, well reported of for good works,” etc., which would that it were fully restored in our churches.

Polanus saith: Deacons are those who collect and distribute the ecclesiastical goods unto those who need them, with simplicity, freely serving even the poorest and vilest (Acts 6:3; Romans 12:8). Deacons ought to be grave, not doubletongued, not given to much wine, not greedy of filthy lucre, holding the mystery of the faith in a pure conscience. And let these also first be proved; then let them use the office of a deacon, being found blameless (1 Timothy 3:8-10). The ecclesiastical goods are divided into four parts:

  1. One is distributed unto those who are addicted unto the ministry of the Church (Matthew 10:10; 1 Corinthians 9:9; 1 Thessalonians 3:8).
  2. Another quarter is expended for feeding the poor, especially the widows of the ministers of the Church and teachers in the schools.
  3. The third is for building the edifices of churches, schools, hospitals, and inns, and for other unforeseen necessities of the Church.
  4. The remaining quarter is conceded unto the bishop, whereby he may receive poor strangers and exiles for the truth of Christ and also help captive brethren when there is need (1 Timothy 3:2; Titus 1:8).

But if the public necessity of the whole republic and Church require it, and other revenues do not suffice, the residue can be sought from the ecclesiastical goods which is required for the conservation of the republic (2 Kings 18:15).

Zanchius saith: Since indeed many goods were formerly donated by the liberality of princes and other pious men, and even now in some places are donated unto the churches, we judge that if any churches have such goods, it must be diligently cared for that they be not squandered nor converted unto profane uses, much less unto sacrilegious, or that they be converted and dissembled, but that they be distributed only unto those for whom they were donated, namely, for pious uses. But we approve that ancient partition of ecclesiastical goods (Deuteronomy 14), that one part, namely, go unto the pious bishops, that is, the doctors and ministers of the word, and their families; another unto the clerks, that is, the students designated for the ministry of the Church, and all who serve the Church; the third unto the poor and strangers; the fourth for repairing churches and schools: unto which part pertain not only the houses of ministers, doctors, students, libraries with their books, instruments, and all other things necessary for churches and schools, but also hospitals, inns, and other like places where those dwell whose peculiar care the churches ought to undertake.

Professor saith: Not only the function of pastors but also of presbyters and deacons was formerly perpetual. Now, because there is less number in our churches than there was formerly in the Apostolic churches of men excellently adorned with zeal for building the house of God and with other spiritual gifts, and less munificence of this age than of the former toward those who serve the Church of Christ, therefore, the change of the continuous function of presbyters and deacons into a biennial one is rather admitted than blamed by us today, especially since some examples of interrupted leitourgia are found in the priests and Levites of the Old Testament (1 Chronicles 24:4), and in Zacharias, the father of John the Baptist (Luke 1:5). And although presbyters and deacons today interrupt their ministry for a longer interval than formerly the priests and Levites, who performed their office by certain weekly turns, yet in this the custom of our churches is to be praised, that it restoreth presbyters and deacons of approved faith and integrity, after the lapse of a few years, unto their former functions. The names and offices of porters, exorcists, lectors, acolytes, and subdeacons appear no more in the above-produced Apostolic descriptions of ecclesiastical ministers than the epithets and offices of archdeacons, curates, monks, abbots, and the like.

Ames saith: Those transcendent members of the hierarchy are mere human creatures introduced into the Church without any divine precept or example: they cannot fulfill the pastoral office in so many congregations; they spoil the churches of their liberty while they exercise over the churches themselves and their pastors a dominion as it were royal, or rather tyrannical; they have introduced with themselves, as the head, the Roman Antichrist himself, and as the tail of the same flour, chancellors, suffragans, archdeacons, officials, and similar props of the hierarchy (whose very names are apocryphal and altogether unknown to the first churches) to oppress utterly the churches of God.

XXIX. Equality Among Ministers

There is no inequality of order or power among the ministers of the word, nor any episcopate by divine right.

Gomarus saith: For that all were equal, the Apostle Paul demonstrateth by his own example, when he testifieth unto the Corinthians that he was in nothing inferior unto the chiefest Apostles (2 Corinthians 11:5), and unto the Galatians:

  1. That nothing was conferred upon him by them (Galatians 2:6).
  2. That the Gospel of the uncircumcision was committed unto him as that of the circumcision unto Peter (Galatians 2:7).
  3. That God had wrought no less through him among the Gentiles than through Peter among the Jews (Galatians 2:8).
  4. That James, Cephas, and John had given the right hand of fellowship, that he with Barnabas should go unto the Gentiles, and they unto the Jews (Galatians 2:9).

Whence the equality of Peter and the other Apostles was rightly demonstrated by the ancient Fathers, Chrysostom and Ambrose, in the same place. And the same is established by the Pontifical law itself, Decretum, Cause 24, Question 2, Canon “Loquitur” (abounding in its contradictions), from Cyprian the Pope (not the Roman but the Carthaginian, for the word “Pope” was formerly common unto bishops, and by that name Cyprian is called by the Roman presbyters, Cyprian, Epistle 17, Book 2, and Augustine by Jerome, Augustine, Volume 2, Epistles 13, 17): “This indeed were the other Apostles what Peter was: endowed with equal fellowship both of honor and of power” (Cyprian, On the Unity of the Church, Section 3). And the same saith Anacletus, Pope of Rome: “The other Apostles received with the same equal fellowship honor and power” (Distinction 21, Canon “In Novo”).

Professor saith: Not by divine but by human institution, after the time of the Apostles, someone from the order of presbyters was placed in authority over others and called bishop by a singular prerogative, as after Jerome, some Papists also confess, namely Lombard, Gratian, Cusanus, and others: Jerome on Titus 1, to Evagrius; Lombard, Book 4, Distinction 24; Gratian, Distinction 93, Canon “Legitimus,” and Distinction 95, Canon “Olim”; Cusanus, De Concordantia Catholica, Book 2, Chapter 13.

Walaeus saith: Concerning the degrees of ministers, it is asked whether among pastors laboring in the word there be any eminence of one above others. We do not deny, indeed, that some order ought to be constituted among pastors where they are many in number or convene, whether that order be temporary or perpetual, provided that tyranny be guarded against; of which the former the French and Belgian churches, the latter the German in their superintendents, have chosen. Nor is it asked whether some inspection over others can be conceded unto one, that order may be preserved and unity better consulted. But this is asked, whether such eminence be that one is superior in degree to another by divine right, so that unto one is conceded power over another, namely, the power of sending or deposing ministers, the power of excommunicating or admitting, of prescribing laws, of ruling, etc., such as the present bishops claim for themselves. We do not yet treat here of secular power but of spiritual or ecclesiastical. But this is what ours deny against the Episcopalians. Our chief arguments are these:

  1. For in the whole Scripture, there is no mention of such eminence and power.
  2. For in those places where there is express mention of the degrees of ministers of the New Testament, Scripture mentioneth only one kind of pastors, as 1 Corinthians 12:28: “And God hath set some in the church, first apostles, secondarily prophets, thirdly teachers.” And Ephesians 4:11. So also Romans 12:6; Acts 20:17-18; 1 Peter 5:1.
  3. For Scripture expressly teacheth that bishops and presbyters were altogether the same, as Acts 20:17: he called the elders; and verse 28: he saith that the Holy Ghost hath made them bishops. So Philippians 1:1: “Paul and Timotheus, the servants of Jesus Christ, to all the saints in Christ Jesus which are at Philippi, with the bishops and deacons.” And Titus 1:5: “For this cause left I thee in Crete, that thou shouldest set in order the things that are wanting, and ordain elders in every city.” And verse 7: “For a bishop must be blameless, as the steward of God.” Whence also Jerome, in his epistle to Evagrius and commentary on Titus, frequently gathereth that the presbyter and bishop are the same; and that one is a name of age, the other of office. So also Ambrose on Ephesians 4 affirmeth that at first all presbyters were called bishops, afterward he who was first in time, so that when one departed, the next succeeded him. So Augustine and very many others in this opinion. See Bucer, p. 258. Finally, from no place of Scripture will it be proved that unto one presbyter or ordinary pastor is given any power, whether in the preaching of the word, for all are teachers and pastors, or in the administration of the sacraments, as Matthew 28:19; 1 Corinthians 11:23, or in the exercise of discipline (1 Corinthians 5:4; 2 Corinthians 2:7), or in the ruling of the Church (Acts 20:17; 1 Peter 5:2; Hebrews 13:17): “Obey them that have the rule over you,” which is not given unto another. Wherefore, the Apostles, in the inscriptions of their epistles, write to the saints, also to the ministers, never to some one bishop alone. And they prescribe rules (1 Timothy 3:2; Titus 1:6; 1 Peter 5:2) common unto all pastors, none singular for bishops.

Objection: The example of Timothy and Titus.

Response: Unto them, indeed, singular power was given, but extraordinary, because they were evangelists, as is expressly said to Timothy (2 Timothy 4:5): “Do the work of an evangelist.” Who also was called according unto the prophecies that went before on him (1 Timothy 1:18). Evangelists are distinguished from pastors (Ephesians 4:11): “Some evangelists, and some pastors and teachers.”

Objection: It is written in Revelation 2 and 3 to the angels of the churches in the singular number.

Response: Some understand by “angels” the churches themselves, because as at the beginning of the epistles it is said, “Unto the angel of the church of Ephesus,” so at the end it is said, “He that hath an ear, let him hear what the Spirit saith unto the churches.” Likewise, Revelation 3:3: “I say unto you, and unto the rest in Thyatira.” But be it that pastors are understood, we say that it is an enallage or synecdoche of number, and it is to be understood collectively, as Malachi 2:7: “The priest’s lips should keep knowledge, and they should seek the law at his mouth: for he is the messenger of the Lord of hosts,” yet it is understood of the whole kind of priests, as appeareth from the consequences and the thing itself.

Objection: Antiquity, for in all ancient writings, mention is made of this order.

Response: But not of that singular power. Then, Jerome noteth the origin in Titus 1: “Before, by the instigation of the devil, there were studies in religion, and it was said among the people, I am of Paul, I of Apollos, I of Cephas, the churches were governed by the common counsel of the presbyters. But after each one thought that those whom he had baptized were his own, not Christ’s, it was received by common decree that one elected from the presbyters should be placed over the rest”:

  1. Also, the archiepiscopate, patriarchate, the order of metropolitans is most ancient, and yet they confess that it is of human institution.
  2. Even then the mystery of iniquity was working, etc. Likewise, the subscriptions of the epistles of Paul to Timothy and Titus, but they are uncertain and of a later age.

XXX. The Rejection of a Supreme Bishop

Not only that one should exalt himself above all as bishop of bishops, which the Roman Pope doth.

Geneva saith: We maintain that those functions are adulterine and destitute of all right foundation: the primacy of the Bishop of Rome over all churches, the cardinalate, patriarchates, archiepiscopates, finally, every degree of the episcopal over his fellow presbyters. Concerning the power usurped by the Bishop of Rome over other, yea, all churches, it is proved, among other manifest causes, not to be Apostolic, and therefore established by no divine right:

  1. One, since the Apostles were altogether equal in authority and right among themselves, as is clear both from the command of Christ sending them and from their own testified deeds.
  2. The other, since the Apostolic function, destined for laying the foundation of the Catholic Christian Church, when it was well laid and the Apostles called into heaven, ceased on earth as to personal ministry; and as to the superstructure, the doctrine delivered by them and divinely preserved and to endure unto the end of the ages sufficeth so far that there is need of no successor of Apostolic authority either for the constitution of new churches or for the restoration of those constituted.

The cardinals were at first called (as appeareth from the history of Fabian and Sylvester, bishops, however depraved) the deacons of the Roman Church, seven from as many regions of the city (whom they also called “hinges”), unto each of whom they were attributed, so called as if “regionaries,” which their very mendicated titles demonstrate. Yea, even in Gregory, a cardinal priest seemeth to be called who is called pastor or curate; nor is there any mention of them who now are in the subscriptions of the ancient synods, so that they can and ought deservedly to be accounted the most foul offspring of Satan in these last ages to foster that harlot. Concerning the distinction of bishops into patriarchs, primates, metropolitans, archbishops (who all at first were the same), Jerome himself testifieth with open words that all that is of human disposition, not of divine institution.

Walaeus saith: The power which the Pontiff taketh unto himself in the Church is such that no vestiges of the thing exist in the Scriptures: as of deposing kings and transferring kingdoms unto whom he will, of releasing subjects from the oath of fidelity, etc. In spiritual things, he maketh articles and holdeth a general synod; he appointeth and deposeth bishops; he prescribeth rites for the churches, even abolishing those instituted by Christ, as is seen in the sacrament of the Supper, etc.; he remitteth sins through indulgences, etc. All which pertain only unto God and Christ, as Scripture testifieth everywhere. Yet Christ, while on earth, usurped not such power: “The kings of the Gentiles exercise lordship over them; but ye shall not be so.” “Not lording it over God’s heritage.” If he is the vicar of Christ, then either of Him reigning in heaven, who needeth no vicar and absolutely ruleth over all, or as He was on earth, and then neither did He release subjects from the oath nor depose kings nor do the other things which the Pontiff taketh unto himself.

Objection: But Peter was the head of the Church, and the Pontiff succeeded him.

Response:

  1. First, from Peter unto the Pontiff there is no consequence, because Peter was an Apostle, and called neither by man nor through man; the Pope is not such.
  2. Second, we deny that Peter was the head of the other Apostles or of the whole Church, such as they will. For Peter is sent into Samaria with John (Acts 8:14); he rendereth account of his actions at Cornelius’s house (Acts 11:4); he giveth his sentence among the rest (Acts 15:7); he calleth others fellow elders (1 Peter 5:1). For what they collect concerning the prerogatives of Peter pertaineth not to the matter, because either they were not prerogatives but common unto him with the other Apostles, or they had a peculiar cause.

    3. Common with the other Apostles:

    1. That Christ changed his name and called him Peter. The cause was that there were two Simons among the Apostles, unto one of whom Christ gave the name Canite or Lebbæus, unto the other Peter or Cephas; so He called John and James Boanerges.
    2. That Christ saith (Matthew 16:18): “Thou art Peter, and upon this rock I will build my church.” And, “I will give unto thee the keys of the kingdom of heaven,” etc. This also pertaineth unto the other Apostles, through whose doctrine the Church of Christ was built (Ephesians 2:20; Revelation 21:14), where it is said that there were twelve foundations of the heavenly Jerusalem, and on them were written the names of the twelve Apostles. Then, James and John are also called with Peter pillars of the Church (Galatians 2:9). The power of binding and loosing is given unto the whole Church (Matthew 18:18) and unto all the Apostles (John 20:22): “When Christ said, Receive ye the Holy Ghost: whose soever sins ye remit,” etc. The prerogative of Peter here can be said that he first began to gather the Church from the Jews (Acts 2:14) and from the Gentiles (Acts 10:23; 15:7). But yet not excluding the other Apostles, as in the text.
    3. That he is always named in the first place. But neither is this true, for James is placed before Peter (Galatians 2:9): “James, Cephas, and John,” and 1 Corinthians 1:12: “I am of Paul; and I of Apollos; and I of Cephas.”

    Peculiar causes in other privileges:

    1. That he is expressly called first (Matthew 10:2): “The first, Simon, who is called Peter, and Andrew his brother,” etc. Response: Here the Apostles are sent by pairs, therefore it was necessary to begin from some one. But he is called first in order because of age and because he was first called unto the apostleship by Christ with his brother Andrew. Also because of zeal, gifts, etc. And for this cause, he oft speaketh first.
    2. Christ paid for himself and Peter the didrachma at Capernaum (Matthew 17:27). But because Peter alone dwelt there with Christ, for there the tribute is paid where one abideth.
    3. Christ said unto Peter after the ascension, “Lovest thou me? Feed my sheep, feed my lambs” (John 21:17). Response:
      1. Rightly doth Augustine say that unto the threefold denial is opposed the threefold confession of repentance and restoration into the office.
      2. All pastors are said to feed the flock (Acts 20:28; 1 Peter 5:2). Therefore, nothing peculiar here.
      3. Third, even if Peter were superior unto the rest, there is no consequence from Peter unto the Pope of Rome:
    4. For Peter’s calling was extraordinary; but that Peter had any other than the Apostolic calling will never be proved from Scripture nor from his epistles, in which he calleth himself an Apostle and fellow elder.
    5. For it will never be proved that anyone peculiarly succeeded Peter, no more than the other Apostles. But what they say, that he sat at Rome, therefore the Pope of Rome succeeded him, by no means followeth. Christ sat at Jerusalem, and yet therefore the bishop of that church was not placed over all the rest.
    6. It is false that he was bishop there, because the Apostolic office is greater than the episcopal and not bound unto a certain place, but he ought to build the Church everywhere, as is also clear from his journeys and from the epistle written unto the dispersed Jews, and from this, that Peter was especially to be occupied in converting the Jews, as Paul testifieth (Galatians 2:7).

Objection: In the Old Testament, there was a high priest placed over the rest. Therefore, it is necessary that some high pastor also in the New Testament preside over the rest.

Response:

  1. The high priest was placed over the Israelite people; therefore, someone now ought to be placed over the whole world; there is no consequence.
  2. The high priesthood of the Old Testament was typical and fulfilled in Christ, who is our high priest (Hebrews 9:11) and our chief shepherd (1 Peter 5:4), and therefore we have need of no other, because He ever liveth to make intercession for us before God, as Paul testifieth (Hebrews 7:25). And therefore, He hath need neither of a successor nor of a vicar.
  3. The high priest of the Old Testament had not such power as they are wont to feign for their Pontiff. Unto the Pope is assigned singular power, spiritual and temporal.

Objection: But the primacy of the Pontiff is very ancient and founded in the practice of the ancient Church.

Response: Among the most ancient, nothing of the sort. Gradually, the bishop of the first see was acknowledged, and among the patriarchs the first, on whose occasion he obtained great authority and daily affected greater. The decretal epistles are feigned, of the same style and almost barbarous, against the style of that age; then, mention is made in them of many things which were not in use in that age. See Rainolds against Hart. Afterward, through the disturbance of the East, which was infected with divers heresies from which Rome was long free, he acquired greater authority, until, with the Roman Empire declining under Honorius and after the invasion of the Lombards and Goths, he gradually claimed political power for himself and called the Gauls into the empire under Pepin and Charles, who for this benefit conceded many things unto him. See Plessis, Mystery of Iniquity; Valla, Against the Donation of Constantine, etc.

Gomarus saith: Then, if Peter was made the ordinary bishop of the Roman Church, who called him unto that particular office? Christ? The Church? Nothing of this appeareth. Yea, whether Peter was ever at Rome (although it be an ancient tradition), many doubt, relying on probable reasons from the Acts of the Apostles and the Epistles. But that he was bishop there for twenty-five years, although it be an ancient and common opinion even of the Pontiffs, yet not undeservedly in the very defense of Peter’s primacy is it confuted by Onuphrius, Book 3, Chapter 1. But be it that he was at Rome for so many years and bishop of that church, will therefore his privileges and peculiar gifts be common unto his successors? Then, will not the bishop of the church of Antioch (whom they affirm to have first succeeded Peter) by the same reason have as much right, and not be inferior unto the Roman bishop but superior by the order of the see and the origin of the Christian name? And thus, the empire of the Roman Pope will collapse. Or because the ancient writers relate that Peter died at Rome, is therefore the bishop of Rome his successor and the monarch of the universal Church? Or is therefore the Roman Church the head of all churches, and obedience must be rendered unto its jurisdiction (as the Roman Pope decreeth) in all things? For thus, treating of Peter and Paul, he saith: “Both consecrated the holy Roman Church and preferred it above all other cities in the whole world, both by their presence and by their venerable triumph.” Anacletus, Pope, Distinction 22, Canon “Sacrosanct.” Pelagius, Pope, Distinction 21, Canon “Quamvis.” But who seeth not, who laugheth not at the vanity of this consequence? For if presence and the triumph of death be regarded, so much more excellent will the Jerusalem Church be as the supreme Lord is greater than His servants. For in this, Jesus Christ, the Son of God, founded the Church, wrought miracles, suffered, and by His death on the cross, triumphing over the devil and sin (Colossians 2:14-15), redeemed the universal Church (Acts 20:28; John 6:51), that we may meanwhile omit the sending of the Holy Spirit, the first preaching of the Apostles, and the propagation of the Gospel thence unto the Gentiles, the first bonds and scourging of Peter, the martyrdoms of James the Greater and the Less, and other ornaments thereof. Wherefore, the reasons of the Roman Pope are altogether vain whereby he arrogateth unto himself the succession of the office and power of Peter; and that the Roman Church, by the Lord’s disposition, obtaineth the principality of ordinary power over all churches, as Innocent III defineth in the Lateran Council. Unto which Jerome, not acknowledging such a disposition of the Lord, freely establisheth the contrary, and that also by the Pontifical law (Distinction 39, Canon “Legimus”), it is related and approved, as appeareth: “If authority be sought,” he saith, “the world is greater than the city. Why dost thou bring forth unto me the custom of one city? Wherever a bishop be, whether at Rome, or at Eugubium, or at Constantinople, or at Rhegium, or at Alexandria, or at Tanis, he is of the same merit and of the same priesthood. The power of riches and the humility of poverty make not a bishop higher or lower. But all are successors of the Apostles.” (Volume 2, Epistle to Evagrius). Wherefore, from all these, the dissension of Peter the Apostle and of the Roman Pope clearly appeareth; and therefore, we deservedly conclude that the Pope is not the successor of Peter the Apostle but his adversary, and that the Roman Church is not Apostolic but apostate. And this the following will further show. For we deny that these sentences of Pope Gregory VII in the Roman Council concerning the privileges of the Pontiffs, which Baronius reciteth, Annals, Book 11, Year 1076, Number 31, are true:

  1. That the Roman Pontiff, if he be canonically ordained, is infallibly holy by the merits of St. Peter.
  2. That the Roman Pontiff alone is rightly called universal.
  3. That no chapter or book is to be held canonical without his authority.
  4. That his sentence ought not to be retracted by any, and he can retract those of all.
