  5. That he ought to be judged by none.
  6. That no one dare condemn one appealing unto the Apostolic see.
  7. That the greater causes of any church ought to be referred unto him.
  8. That no synod ought to be called general without his precept.
  9. That it is lawful for him to depose emperors.
  10. That he can absolve subjects from the fidelity of the wicked.

XXXI. The Presbyterial Senate

Presbyters, for ruling the Church, constitute a senate, which is either of one church or of many.

Spanheim saith: From the collection of these pastors and presbyters, who are wont to be called elders akribōs, is constituted the presbytery or assembly, occupied with preserving order in the Church, with either preventing or averting scandals, with drawing ecclesiastical censures, and with promoting all those things which make for edification, with legitimate ecclesiastical means, either preventing or removing those things which intervene (Matthew 16:17; 2 Timothy 1:6).

Professor saith: But an ecclesiastical convention is a session instituted by Christ of the whole Church, according unto the proportion of its amplitude, represented in the chief members of the Church and gathered in one place in the name of Christ, to treat there of the affairs of the Church, namely, of the health of faith, the holiness of life, the integrity of the sacraments, the goodness of order, etc., and of its practice or use and observance, for its right government and edification and the glory of God. And it is either of single churches or of many:

  1. Of single churches, indeed, is the legitimate and almost perpetual and standing session, constituted of the bishop or bishops of one place (Philippians 1:1; Acts 20:28; 21:18; Titus 1:5,7), and of the presbyters, that is, the elders or deputies of the people (as integrating parts of the Church), for treating the affairs which are proper unto that single church. And it is called a sanhedrin or consistory (Matthew 26:59; John 11:47). By Paul, it is called a presbytery, that is, a senate or college of elders (1 Timothy 4:14). And this session is first in origin.
  2. But of many churches is the congress from a lower session unto a certain place and time of more ecclesiastical persons, namely, of pastors and rulers, sent to treat those things which regard many churches and could not be accomplished in the lower single session. And it is generally called a synod in Greek, a council in Latin, from “conciere” (to call together). And it is either of one diocese or jurisdiction or of many.
  3. Of one, indeed, it is commonly called a classis or diocesan synod or local.
  4. But of many dioceses or of some whole province, specifically a synod or council.

But a synod or council (that we may collect all the preceding) is a public and legitimate convention of the Church, and that more august and ample, instituted by Christ, represented indeed through persons delegated from the lower convention unto a certain place and time, chiefly bishops and presbyters, and gathered in the name of God and Christ, to treat, judge, and constitute from the word of God those things which regard the common state of the churches and which could not be accomplished in the lower classical sessions, especially when it treateth of the purity of faith and truth against the erring and heretics, of morals and order against schismatics, for the edification, integrity, and peace of the Church. Moreover, it is either provincial, or national, or general, or plenary, as they call it, or ecumenical or universal, which is gathered from persons and treateth of the affairs of the churches of a whole province, of one or more nations, or of the universal Church.

XXXII. Ecclesiastical Discipline

No small part of the ministry and power of the Church is engaged in the well-exercising of discipline.

Junius saith: Discipline, properly from “discere” (to learn), is the observation of laws and ordinances passively; but improperly, it also taketh on an active signification and is restricted unto the institution of morals. In which sense, this ecclesiastical discipline is defined as the power immediately given by Christ unto the Church whereby brethren fallen into sins are admonished, reproved, and, if they be impenitent and contumacious, are excommunicated, for the glory of God and the salvation of the Church. By power, we understand not autokratorikē (which is of Christ alone, Matthew 28:18; John 17:2), but hypēretikē, ministerial, subordinate, and defined (1 Corinthians 5:4; 2 Corinthians 10:8), which repugneth not unto the former unto which it subserveth. The efficient cause of this discipline is Christ, who instituted it and gave unto His Church the power of binding and loosing (Matthew 16:19). Since, therefore, this power is not of positive or human right, which can be changed or abrogated, but of divine right, it followeth that this discipline is immovable and immutable, which is to be noted that no one may think that he can by good right take away from the Church this power, which proceeded not at all from men. The instrumental cause is the Church, that is, the senate of presbyters, or, as it is called by Paul, the presbytery, which succeeded the Jewish sanhedrin by the institution of Christ; and in private sins, also individual brethren (1 Timothy 4:14). The matter about which are the sins, whether private or public, of all those who are members of the visible Church and are therefore called brethren (Matthew 18:15), and these as well subjects as magistrates, in government as well political as ecclesiastical (1 Corinthians 5:11). The form is the mode prescribed by Christ (Matthew 18:15-18).

Trelcatius saith: Ecclesiastical power is threefold: of the ministry, of order, and of ecclesiastical discipline. The power of the ministry is the authority and right of teaching in the Church, not anything whatsoever, but that one thing which the Lord prescribed through His prophets and Apostles (Galatians 1:8; 1 Timothy 6:3), and it is the former part of the keys. The power of order is the faculty of the Church which is engaged both concerning doctrine and concerning laws of external polity to be constituted, the former dogmatikē, the latter taktikē, that is, it is commonly called ordinated. Ecclesiastical discipline is the kritikē or judicial power of the Church whereby men received into the family of Christ are directed unto piety and restrained that they commit nothing unworthy of the Christian profession, and sinners are reproved, rebuked, and corrected.

Ames saith: Sacred discipline is the personal application of the will of God through censures to prevent or remove scandals from the Church of God. For in the preaching of the word, the will of God is proposed and really applied to beget and increase faith and obedience. In the administration of the sacraments, the will of God is also personally applied by seals to confirm faith and obedience. In the exercise of discipline, the will of God is also personally applied by censures to remove those vices which fight against true faith and obedience. Hence it is that discipline is wont to be joined with the word and sacraments by the best theologians in noting the Church of God. This discipline was instituted and prescribed by Christ Himself (Matthew 16:19; 18:15-16). And so, it is altogether of divine right, nor can it be taken away, diminished, or changed by men at their discretion. Yea, he sinneth against Christ the author and institutor, whosoever doth not what in him lieth to constitute and promote this discipline in the churches of God.

Walaeus saith: That some power is given unto the Church which is spiritual and not carnal, the Apostle expressly testifieth (2 Corinthians 10:4), where he saith: “The weapons of our warfare are not carnal, but mighty through God to the pulling down of strong holds, casting down imaginations, and every high thing that exalteth itself against the knowledge of God.” Which weapons he explaineth by the word of power (verse 8), when he saith: “The Lord hath given us power for edification, and not for destruction.” Just as it is usual that power is signified by a key, as in Revelation 1:18: “I have the keys of hell and of death.” So chapter 3:7 and 9:1: “I saw an angel which had the key of the bottomless pit,” and 20:1. So this power is elsewhere expressed by Scripture through the word of keys, as Matthew 16:19, when Christ saith unto Peter: “I will give unto thee the keys of the kingdom of heaven.” So also Revelation 3:7 it is said of Christ Himself: “These things saith he that is holy, he that is true, he that hath the key of David, he that openeth, and no man shutteth; and shutteth, and no man openeth.” Therefore, unto Christ as Lord is given this key in the Church of God, unto Peter and the Apostles as ministers and ambassadors of Christ, and therefore to be used only according unto Christ’s prescription, just as the Apostle admonisheth (1 Corinthians 4:1): “Let a man so account of us, as of the ministers of Christ, and stewards of the mysteries of God: moreover it is required in stewards, that a man be found faithful.” This power of the keys is explained a little more fully by what followeth (Matthew 16:19): “Whatsoever thou shalt bind on earth shall be bound in heaven: and whatsoever thou shalt loose on earth shall be loosed in heaven.” And John 20:23: “Whose soever sins ye remit, they are remitted unto them; and whose soever sins ye retain, they are retained.” Therefore, this power which is metaphorically understood by keys is the power of binding or loosing, of remitting or retaining sins. For just as by a key someone is admitted into some house and again let out, so also by this power, heaven is shut or opened unto men, sins are remitted or retained. There is controversy concerning the key which is called discipline. And although there be some who bear private admonitions ill, yet more who will not acknowledge this power.

Question: It is asked, therefore, whether any other power is given unto pastors and churches than that of the word?

Answer: We answer that, although Erastus and some among the modern writers scarcely acknowledge it but refer all these unto the magistrate, yet another power is given unto the Church of Christ. Which we must demonstrate against them: then, what that is and how it is to be exercised. That some spiritual power against those who are in the Church is given unto the pastors and elders of the Church, which consisteth in exclusion from participation in the signs of grace, is demonstrated by the following arguments:

I. From the Old Testament:

  1. For God Himself excluded man from the signs of grace, namely, from the tree of life and paradise, after our first parents had openly violated that covenant; as also afterward Cain, whom He commanded to go into exile from His face, that is, from that place where God represented the signs of His grace, as also afterward Esau and Ishmael from the family of Jacob and from the promise of Canaan, which was also a sign that in the blessed seed all nations should be blessed.
  2. And lest anyone think that it is not lawful for us to imitate what God Himself did or commanded, God also after the law was given commandeth this to be observed in the Church of the Old Testament. First, by the exclusion of those who according unto the law were unclean, concerning whom it is to be seen in Leviticus 5:2; 7:11; 13:2, where is the law concerning lepers; and Numbers 19:7 concerning those who were unclean when the Passover was celebrated; likewise, Exodus 12:48 forbiddeth that any uncircumcised person eat thereof. These are clear. But that a firm argument may be drawn hence, two things are briefly to be confirmed:
    1. That this judgment was in the hands of the Levites and priests, not only in the hands of each one concerning himself, nor in the hands of the magistrate, as they except.
    2. That this also ought to be drawn into example in moral uncleanness.

II. Arguments from the New Testament are almost these:

  1. From Matthew 16:19: “I will give unto thee the keys of the kingdom of heaven: and whatsoever thou shalt bind on earth shall be bound in heaven: and whatsoever thou shalt loose on earth shall be loosed in heaven.” John 20:23: “Whose soever sins ye remit, they are remitted unto them; and whose soever sins ye retain, they are retained.” Here the power of remitting is expressly given unto the Apostles. Here two things are answered:
    1. First, that by binding and loosing, likewise by remitting and retaining sins, is understood only the preaching of the Gospel.
    2. Second, that these are said unto the Apostles, which therefore do not pertain unto all other pastors.

      3. Both these exceptions are validly refuted from Matthew 18:18, where the same words are repeated concerning the Church, which ought to be perpetual.

  2. The place Matthew 18:15: “If thy brother shall trespass against thee, go and tell him his fault,” etc. “If he will not hear the church, let him be unto thee as an heathen man and a publican. Verily I say unto you,” etc. This place the whole ancient, yea, the whole Christian Church had for the confirmation of this discipline, yet Erastus endeavoreth to weaken it, excepting that here it treateth of private injuries and lighter ones which happen among brethren, and of the way of composing them. But if they cannot be composed, that then the Jewish sanhedrin be approached, which he will have understood by the word “church”; but if he will not hear them, then he is to be had as a heathen and a publican, that is, to be referred unto the Gentile magistrate. But the absurdity of this exposition is evident of itself:
    1. For never in the whole Scripture of the New Testament is this word so taken, but always for the Church of Christ, except that once inActs 19:32it is called “the lawful assembly” of the citizens. But here, without doubt, Matthew useth the word “church” not otherwise than in chapter 16:18, when Christ said unto Peter: “Upon this rock I will build my church.” For what is said, that then the Church was not yet gathered:
      1. It is denied, for both the seventy disciples and the Apostles themselves had already begun to gather the Church; and Christ could speak of the Church to be erected, although not yet erected.
      2. Some think that Christ hath respect unto the ecclesiastical judgments of the Jews in each city and speaketh from their use and transferreth it unto Christians. But whatever it be, we deny that at least here by “church” is understood the Jewish sanhedrin, because otherwise all the faithful, in such offenses, would have had to go up unto Jerusalem, where that sanhedrin alone was.
    2. It is unheard of that these words, “Let him be unto thee as an heathen man,” etc., signify to refer the brother unto the Gentile magistrates, and indeed by command, “Let him be unto thee,” etc., since the Apostle (1 Corinthians 6:1) reproveth Christians that they had suits before the Gentile judges against brethren.
    3. Finally, that those words, “Whatsoever ye shall bind on earth,” etc., are understood of the sentence of the civil magistrate, and indeed of the Gentile, is likewise unheard of, since the same words are in chapter 16 in Christ’s sentence unto Peter, where necessarily ecclesiastical power and divine ratification are understood.

Objection: But he saith, “Let him be unto thee as an heathen man,” etc., he doth not say, “Let him be unto the whole church.”

Response: It is manifest that this manner of speaking is usual, even when it treateth of the multitude, that it be a pleonasm or enallage of number, which is demonstrated from the following words: “Verily I say unto you, Whatsoever ye shall bind,” etc., which manifestly are said of many. But what is said, that it treateth here only of private injuries, is not true, but it treateth of injuries wounding the conscience and excluding a man from heaven unless he repent, because it is said: “It shall be bound in heaven,” likewise, “If he shall hear the church, thou hast gained thy brother.” It is one thing to gain, another only to pacify.

Objection: The testimony from 1 Corinthians 5:4, where the Apostle, treating of the incestuous person to be delivered unto Satan and to be removed from among them, lest a little leaven leaven the whole lump, commandeth that they deliver him unto Satan: “When ye are gathered together, and my spirit, with the power of our Lord Jesus Christ, to deliver such an one unto Satan for the destruction of the flesh, that the spirit may be saved in the day of the Lord Jesus,” etc. And afterward, he prescribeth a general rule how they ought thenceforth to behave themselves toward such authors of scandals. Here Erastus excepteth that by delivering unto Satan is understood to give them to be killed by Satan; likewise, to remove from among them is to take away life miraculously, as was done unto Ananias and Sapphira by Peter (Acts 5:5).

Response: That it is not so to be understood, the manner of speaking and Paul’s explanation prove. For to deliver unto Satan is equivalent unto what he said in verse 2, “To put away from among yourselves,” that is, to remove from the assembly of the faithful; the end also showeth this (verse 5): “That such an one be delivered unto Satan for the destruction of the flesh, that the spirit may be saved.” How can a sinner to be killed in sin be said that the spirit may be saved? But on the contrary, this discipline maketh that the spirit may at length be superior unto the flesh, that is, unto that corrupt nature, and so the man may be saved in the day of the Lord, just as 1 Timothy 1:20: “Of whom is Hymenaeus and Alexander, whom I have delivered unto Satan, that they may learn not to blaspheme.” Which to be said of the dead is absurd. Therefore, delivering unto Satan is ejection outside the Church, where Satan hath his kingdom; or, as Chrysostom and Augustine think, with ejection from the Church was conjoined some power and vexation of Satan until they repented. This the third general precept proveth, which on this occasion he subjoineth in the same chapter: namely, not to keep company with such, to purge out the old leaven, not to eat with them, etc., which cannot be understood of the dead. Otherwise, it is absurd that the Apostles or the churches should have killed all the covetous, drunkards, unjust, fornicators, railers, etc., and that miraculously, since on the contrary, they are commanded to pray for all who have not sinned unto death (1 John 5:16). Other places from Romans 16:17; Galatians 5:12; Philippians 3:2; 2 Timothy 3:10, etc.; 2 John 10, etc., are to be brought forth by us afterward.

Objection: It is objected that Christ admitted Judas. Then, that at least appeal may be made unto the magistrate, by the example of Paul. Concerning Judas, some think that he went out from the company of Christ before Christ instituted the Supper, namely, immediately after the dipping of the sop and Christ’s word unto him: “That thou doest, do quickly.”

Response: We answer that it followeth not: Christ admitted Judas the traitor unto the Supper; therefore, no impious persons are to be kept from it. For Judas was then still a hypocrite and a secret traitor, known unto Christ alone; and in that case, we acknowledge that unless the thing can be proved by fit witnesses or is public, no one is to be kept from it, even if it were known unto the pastor alone, because God gave the law that in the mouth of two or three witnesses every word may be established. But Christ would not here act as God or as one furnished with divine authority, but as man and minister of the Father.

Objection: 1 Corinthians 11:28: The Apostle saith, “Let a man examine himself, and so let him eat of that bread, and drink of that cup.”

Response: Subordinates do not fight; for a man ought to examine himself both in secret and in manifest sins. But the pastors and rulers of the Church only in manifest ones, as is sufficiently proved from Matthew 18:17; 1 Corinthians 5:2,7: “Put away from among yourselves that wicked person,” likewise, “Purge out the old leaven,” etc.

Exception: It is excepted by some that this power of the Church was extraordinary and, as they say, given unto the Church for a time and by provision until there were Christian magistrates.

Response:

  1. This is said without Scripture.
  2. It is said against Scripture, because the order constituted by Christ in the Church ought to be perpetual; whence also the churches are reproved which were more negligent herein, as is seen in1 Corinthians 5:1and Revelation 2:14, where the angel of the church of Pergamos is reproved because he bore such men in the Church.
  3. Even before Christ in the Old Testament, it was under the kings.
  4. The whole first Church used it, both before and after the times of Constantine, yea, all Christian churches unto this time.

Question: With this doctrine thus established beyond controversy, another opinion is set forth by some others: namely, that indeed this probation is in the hands of the Church, but that unto him who complaineth that he is unjustly kept or excommunicated, it is lawful to appeal unto the magistrate. It is asked, therefore, what is to be established here.

Response: We deny that properly called appeal or appellation is lawful for anyone to refer such a cause unto the supreme or subordinate magistrate. Because properly called appeal requireth that the same power be in him unto whom appeal is made and in him from whom appeal is made; but the power of the keys or of excommunication is not in the hands of the political magistrate, as is now shown. Then, no example of such appeal existeth in Scripture or in ecclesiastical history of the first Church. But if anyone will appeal from a lesser congregation unto a greater, it is to be appealed unto one of the same nature and power; as in the Old Testament there was that great sanhedrin, concerning which Deuteronomy 17:9 and 2 Chronicles 19:8, as was seen before when we treated of the elders.

Objection: The example of Jeremiah (chapter 26, etc.), who, when he was injured by the priests, was saved by the princes of the people.

Response: There it treateth not of excommunication but of the violence which the priests prepared against the prophet because of his prophecy.

Objection: The example of Paul, who appealed from the chief priests unto Caesar’s tribunal (Acts 25:11).

Response: And this is of another kind, because he was accused of rebellion against Caesar and was in danger of his life; then, properly, he did not appeal from a sentence already passed but declined the tribunal of Festus, because he seemed about to deliver him unto the Jews, as the text is manifest in the place now cited. Yet Beza confesseth, against Erastus, and we also confess, that it can happen that a subject be manifestly injured in the ecclesiastical forum, and there be no superior, or there an unjust sentence be pronounced; then the magistrate can, by office, hear the complaints of such a man and hinder the sentence of excommunication until the matter be more fully examined either by the same synod or by others, as we see that Constantine did in the cause of Athanasius, and the Saxon in the cause of Luther. The words of Beza are: “Since also from a rightly constituted consistory, injury can be done unto the accused in narrower territories, without that violation of the ecclesiastical order, the Christian magistrate, as the guardian and avenger of both tables and of the ecclesiastical eutaxia, can provide for those complaining.”

Martyr saith: It is the opinion of some that anciently, when the magistrates were Gentiles, excommunication could have place, but not today when the magistrate is Christian, who by the sword and civil punishments removeth evil from the midst of the cities and the Church. But let these know that there are very many vices at which civil laws connive, such as adulteries, drunkennesses, evil-speaking, and the like, which yet cannot be borne by the Church. Then, the magistrate oft punisheth with money, with certain exile and prison for a time, by which punishments paid, he restoreth the citizens, nor requireth any repentance; but the Church cannot at all reconcile any but the penitent. Therefore, let not the powers be confounded: let one be civil, the other ecclesiastical. Yet we deny not that princes or the magistrate have that architectonic power whereby, although they exercise not each office and art in the republic, yet they take care that all be done by due reason; and if the ministers of the Church behave not well, they correct them, as David, Joash, Hezekiah, and Josiah reformed religion and the priests.

XXXIII. The Two Parts of Discipline: Correction and Excommunication

The parts of discipline are twain: Correction and Excommunication.

Junius saith: The parts be two: fraternal correction and excommunication. Fraternal correction is an action pertaining unto discipline, whereby brethren, out of charity, are reproved for sins committed and earnestly admonished unto repentance. It dealeth, moreover, with a twofold object, to wit, private sins and public sins. In private sins, three degrees are to be observed: the first, that he who hath sinned be privately and secretly reproved by those alone who are privy unto the sin, and, if it may be, moved unto repentance (Matthew 18:15). The second, that if he repent not at the first reproof, he be again admonished with one or two witnesses joined thereto (Matthew 18:16). Which duty, though it belong to any Christian, yet especially the presbyters, who are set over the governance of the Church, ought to be chosen therefor. The third degree is, that if he remain obstinate and rebellious even unto the admonition of these, the matter be brought unto the church, that is, unto the presbytery, by whom he is to be admonished of his duty (Matthew 18:17). For ere it come unto excommunication, all means must be assayed, that, if it may be done with the word of God preserved, the sinner be retained within the Church. But in public sins, this gradation is not to be kept; rather, because they are committed with public offense, it behoveth forthwith to proceed unto the solemn reproof of the Church, according to the testimony and example of Paul (1 Timothy 5:20; Galatians 2:14). In fraternal correction, moreover, these things are to be observed:

  1. First, that it be done out of charity.
  2. Second, that circumstances be regarded:
    1. Of place, lest that which was done in secret be reproved in public.
    2. Of time, and that according to the measure of the offense, so that one sin be reproved straightway in flagrante delicto, another after the deed; for in vain shall a drunkard be charged with drunkenness when sober.
    3. Of the person, who, if he be superior, the correction must be more modestly applied, lest the man’s authority be dishonored and his calling scorned; if inferior, more sharply and freely.
  3. Third, that patience be employed, and hastiness avoided.
  4. Fourth, that moderation be maintained, lest either by overmuch leniency vices be nourished, or by overmuch severity men be not led unto salvation but driven therefrom.

Thus much concerning the first part of discipline.

Ames saith: The parts of this discipline are fraternal correction and excommunication. For it consisteth not only, nor chiefly, in the thunderbolt of excommunications and anathemas, but most especially in Christian correction. Nor is the proper end of reproof to open a way unto excommunication (though by accident that sometimes followeth), but that the necessity of excommunication, if it may be, be prevented, and the sinner by timely repentance retained in the Church. Correction, reproof, or admonition ought to be applied unto every sin meet for the remedy of discipline, yet in divers manners, according to the diversity of secret and known sins. For in secret sins, those three degrees prescribed by Christ in order are to be observed (Matthew 18:15-17); but in public sins, such gradation is not needful (1 Timothy 5:20). These admonitions must ever be drawn from the word of God, not from human decrees, else they shall not pierce the conscience.

XXXIV. Excommunication: Its Nature and Application

Excommunication is an ecclesiastical censure or penalty, whereby they who show themselves disobedient and contumacious unto the foregoing corrections are barred from the holy communion.

Martyr saith: Excommunication is the casting out of a transgressor from the society of the faithful, by the judgment of the chief men, with the whole Church consenting, by the authority of Christ and the rule of Holy Scripture, for the salvation of him who is cast out and of the people of God.

Junius saith: The power of excommunication pertaineth unto the Church by the authority of Christ, and that true, and is to be exercised by the whole presbytery lawfully chosen (not, however, by one alone at his own discretion), and is to be pronounced in the congregation of the people, so that it be done with their consent, either tacit or express; for (as Pope Leo rightly saith) those things which pertain unto all ought to be done with the consent of all. Whence it followeth that the excommunications of the Papists are by the law itself null (Matthew 18:18). But they alone are to be excommunicated, and all they, who, being called brethren, are contumacious in their sins (Matthew 18:15). Brethren alone, indeed, for the Church judgeth not them that are without (1 Corinthians 5:12), and they who are not in communion cannot be cast out therefrom; the contumacious alone, also, not others for them or with them, for every man shall bear his own burden (Galatians 6:5). Therefore, Augustine justly reproveth a certain bishop Auxilius (Epistle 75), for that he excommunicated the whole family of Classicianus for his sin. But all such, so that none, of whatsoever estate or condition, ecclesiastical or civil, superior or inferior, may deem himself exempt; for the authority of the magistrate is no more diminished than that which detracteth from the kingdom of Christ. Which thing the godly emperors knew well: Theodosius the Elder (Sozomen, Ecclesiastical History, Book 7), Valentinian the First (Theodoret, Ecclesiastical History, Book 4, Chapter 5), submitting themselves unto ecclesiastical discipline.

XXXV. Causes for Excommunication

They are to be excommunicated who grievously sin in doctrine or in life.

Junius saith: The causes for which men are excommunicated are sins, both those public in themselves and those which, from private sins, through lawful process (Matthew 18:15), have become such; and these, whether against the first table or the second (1 Corinthians 5:11), joined with contumacy and committed with offense unto the Church. Thus, hypocrites, so long as their hypocrisy remaineth hidden from all and they be not convicted thereof, neither can nor ought to be excommunicated. The Anabaptists also err, who excommunicate their own for sins committed simply, without contumacy, without preceding admonition and the just order of charity.

Walaeus saith: Concerning the second matter, namely, against whom discipline is to be exercised, the command of Christ is plain (Matthew 18:17), and of the Apostle (1 Corinthians 5:5), to wit, against brethren only, and those who are members of the Church; for the Lord shall judge them that are without (1 Corinthians 5:13). But the cause is a perverse life (Matthew 18:15): “If thy brother shall trespass against thee.” Likewise, 1 Corinthians 5:2; 2 Thessalonians 3:6: “We command you, brethren, in the name of our Lord Jesus Christ, that ye withdraw yourselves from every brother that walketh disorderly, and not after the tradition which he received of us.” And perverse doctrine (Romans 16:17): “Now I beseech you, brethren, mark them which cause divisions and offenses contrary to the doctrine which ye have learned; and avoid them.” And 1 Timothy 1:20: “Of whom is Hymenaeus and Alexander; whom I have delivered unto Satan, that they may learn not to blaspheme.” And Titus 3:10; 2 John 10. These places are manifest; and the reason is, that both a wicked life and wicked doctrine are leaven which leaveneth the whole lump, and therefore must be purged out (Matthew 18:17; 1 Corinthians 5:7).

Query: May another be excommunicated for the offense of one, as a whole family for the sin of the father, or a people for the sins of the magistrate or prince?

Response: Among the Papists, indeed, this is done, but without any example of Scripture. For what is alleged of Dathan or Abiram, or of Achan, who with his whole family suffered punishment, pertaineth not hereto: both because it was a civil penalty, and because it proceeded from the express command of God, and finally, because before God all were guilty of death by their nature, as we read also of the Sodomites and the first world. But God hath given us precepts that the son be not put to death for the father, and likewise, “The soul that sinneth, it shall die” (Ezekiel 18:20). Also, “Every man shall bear his own burden” (Galatians 6:5). And, “I would they were even cut off which trouble you” (Galatians 5:12). Nor is there aught in Scripture whereby it is hinted that this is to be done by the Church, unless perchance they be guilty of the same offense. Wherefore, the Pontiff erreth herein, who sometimes excommunicateth whole cities or kingdoms for the offense of the king.

XXXVI. Degrees of Excommunication

And the Church observeth degrees in pronouncing sentence: whence there is reckoned a lesser excommunication and a greater.

Junius saith: Excommunication is twofold: lesser and greater. The lesser is that whereby they who shamefully offend against faith, good morals, or public order are excommunicated—not that they wholly cease to be accounted members of Christ, but are only for a time barred from the Lord’s Supper until their repentance, faith, or duty be judged sufficient, and remedy be brought unto the public scandal. These were called by the ancients “abstenti” (Cyprian, in his Epistles). The greater is the sacred action of the presbytery, whereby, according to the rule delivered by Christ, a brother contumacious in sins is separated from the communion of the faithful, and, being cast out of the Church, is delivered unto Satan, that, being chastised, he may repent, and, repentance being shown, may be received. This, under the Old Testament, was “to be put out of the synagogue” (John 9:22; 12:42; 16:2). And so, in the ancient Church, excommunication was distinguished through four degrees, whereof the first was called synistamenoi, the second hypopiptontes, the third akroamenoi, the fourth prosklaiontes. For so the canons distinguish, wherein synistamenoi, hypopiptontes, akroamenoi, and prosklaiontes are named in the Council of Caesarea, Canon 15. The first pertaineth unto the lesser, the rest unto the greater excommunication.

Ames saith: Full excommunication is not to be applied unless unto sin be added contumacy (Matthew 18:17). For a sinner duly admonished must needs appear either penitent or contumacious: the penitent is not to be excommunicated; therefore, the contumacious alone. Yet in more heinous crimes, neither necessary nor profitable is such patience and delay to await repentance or discern contumacy, as in more common offenses. When the matter itself can bear delay, it accordeth with Scripture and reason that excommunication first begin with suspension or abstention from the Supper and like privileges of the Church, which is wont to be called lesser excommunication. Yet in this degree it must not rest, but repentance must be urged in this manner and time, and, that being despaired of, it behoveth at length to proceed unto full separation from the communion of the faithful, which is called greater excommunication. And because a contumacious sinner cannot be separated from the faithful unless the faithful also separate themselves from him, and this also maketh for their wholesome shame (2 Thessalonians 3:14), therefore they who are lawfully excommunicated are to be avoided by all communicants—not as touching moral duties simply or other needful things, but as touching those parts of conversation which are wont to carry approbation and inward familiarity. “Os, orare, vale, convivia, mensa negatur.”

Walaeus saith: Concerning the reason of lesser excommunication, it is asked whether it hath foundation in Scripture. Certainly, in the early Church, its common use is beyond controversy, for the abstenti and penitents were distinguished from the excommunicated and had a peculiar place in the Church, as is known. The reason also is clear: though one, after committing some grave offense and scandal in the Church, profess repentance, yet for a time the Church must examine whether the repentance be earnest, which ought to be gathered from its fruits—so that meanwhile the scandal be removed from the offended members of the Church, and as his offense, so also his repentance, become known unto others. Yet we acknowledge that the ancients were stricter in appointing the time of repentance than the Apostolic custom seemeth to require. But besides these, certain foundations for this discipline of the Church are to be brought forth:

  1. First, it is drawn from the abstenti in the Old Testament, who, for ceremonial or moral uncleanness (as shown above), were compelled to abstain from the common sacrifices and sacraments until they were purged and reconciled by peculiar signs of repentance and sacrifices; yet for this they were not cast out of the Church nor rooted out from the people.
  2. The place 1 Corinthians 5 and 2 Corinthians 2:6-7, compared together, also prove this. For Paul judgeth that the incestuous man be excommunicated; he, by repentance, prevented it, and they ask the Apostle what then is to be done. To which he answereth in the second epistle that he must not be overwhelmed with overmuch sorrow, but that the rebuke by many sufficeth, and therefore willeth that he be received again by the Church. Here, indeed, he professed repentance in the meantime, and yet without doubt was abstinent until they received the Apostle’s answer.
  3. From the place 1 Corinthians 11:28: “Let a man examine himself, and so let him eat of that bread, and drink of that cup.” If, therefore, it lieth upon each to examine himself lest he eat unworthily, so also it lieth upon the rulers of the churches to examine others, lest they eat unworthily and eat or drink judgment unto themselves or with the scandal of others, as he saith at the chapter’s end: “Give none offense, neither to the Jews, nor to the Gentiles.”
  4. Some also hold that lesser excommunication is hinted at in the words of Christ (Matthew 18:17): “Let him be unto thee as an heathen man and a publican,” who could pray in the temple and be there (Luke 18:13), though he partook not of the sacrifices or sacraments. Yet Beza, against Erastus, judgeth otherwise, that the speech here increaseth, for the publican was more hated than the Gentile; thus, he could not be excluded from the temple because they were servants of the Romans and Jews, whom they dared not exclude, or were in the outermost part of the temple, where Gentiles also could appear (1 Kings 8:41). But afterward, under Herod, the court of the Gentiles seemeth distinguished from the court of the people.
  5. 1 Corinthians 10:21: “Ye cannot be partakers of the Lord’s table, and of the table of devils.” Likewise, 1 Corinthians 5:11: “With such an one no not to eat.” Therefore, much less is it lawful to grant them the Supper. In 1 Corinthians 10, the Apostle treateth of that which cannot rightfully and with good conscience be done, and thus it is unlawful.

Objection: It is objected that God straightway forgiveth the penitent, therefore the Church ought also.

Response: True, when it is established unto the Church; likewise, when it can be done with edification, for the Church is not a searcher of hearts and must attend unto scandals or the edification of the weak (Romans 14:13).

Objection 1 by Erastus: All the circumcised could celebrate the Passover with others, yea, it was enjoined upon all fathers of families (Exodus 12:4). Therefore, also the Supper.

Response: The antecedent is denied, for the unclean according to the law were compelled to abstain for a whole month, that meanwhile they might purge themselves (Numbers 9:10; 2 Chronicles 30:17).

Objection 2: If it be not lawful for any Christian to separate himself from the Supper without the crime of schism, because of vices reigning in many in the Church, provided the doctrine be pure, therefore neither is it lawful for the Church to separate any from the Supper, provided the confession be pure.

Response: The consequence is denied, for the reason differeth for a private man and for the whole Church or its rulers: for unto them it is commanded to watch lest the sacraments be profaned, and to distinguish between the clean and unclean with public authority, which private persons may not take upon themselves; for that is a remedy against vices, but this violateth charity.

Objection 3: Christ (1 Corinthians 11:28) commandeth all to eat of that bread and drink of that cup, provided they examine themselves.

Response: But if they examine not themselves, and meanwhile will eat of this bread and drink of this cup, it is not therefore to be permitted them, if the matter be manifest, lest they eat unto themselves a heavier judgment, as we have heard of the unclean in the Old Testament.

Objection 4: 1 Corinthians 10:2 saith that all the fathers ate the same spiritual meat and drank the same spiritual drink, which answereth unto the Supper. But many of them were wicked. Therefore.

Response: The reason differeth: for this meat and drink was not only sacramental but also corporal; then, God punished them; thirdly, the multitude caused greater negligence herein.

Objection 5: But there were many drunkards, fornicators, idolaters in the Corinthian Church, and yet he commandeth not that they be kept from the Supper.

Response: Though he commandeth not this everywhere, yet he commanded it in 1 Corinthians 5:4. For he who commandeth the greater commandeth also the lesser. Then, he who forbiddeth eating bread with them much more forbiddeth the Supper. Finally, he himself threateneth (2 Corinthians 10:6) that he will come unto them with a rod unless they do their duty.

The Greater Excommunication: The greater excommunication is so called when he who is named a brother, for grave impurity of doctrine or life, after the private and public admonitions of the Church despised, and contumacious in his sin, is pronounced—not only from the holy Supper, but also before the whole Church, in the name of God, by public sentence on earth and consequently in heaven—to be excluded from the communion of the Church, for so long as, by true and earnest repentance, he be reconciled unto God and the Church. This excommunication is also called by the Apostle a delivering unto Satan (1 Corinthians 5:5; 1 Timothy 1:20), because he who is cast out of the Church is cast into the kingdom of Satan, who reigneth without the Church of Christ. Though Chrysostom and Augustine thought that in the early Church such a man was also delivered unto Satan to be corporally vexed. The same Apostle calleth it there the purging out of the leaven and the putting away from among the Church. But Christ saith (Matthew 18:17): “Let him be unto thee as an heathen man and a publican,” with whom, to wit, he may have no communion of sacred things, with respect unto all the signs of grace which God maketh for His Church.

In this definition, certain parts are to be explained, besides those expounded above concerning the instrumental cause and the subject; and that against the Mennonites, who excommunicate for any cause and rend their churches, as is seen in the example of sellers and buyers of houses:

  1. First, it is not used for the daily infirmities of men, but only against those who grievously sin against the doctrine or precepts of God, as is explained in1 Corinthians 5:5, for which men are excluded from the kingdom of God and which are of great scandal unto the Church, asGalatians 5:12: “I would they were even cut off which trouble you.” Likewise, Romans 16:17; 1 Timothy 1:20.

    2. Query: Is it for light offenses? Thus, for a debt of money contracted without fraud, bishops excommunicate, though such may be godly (2 Kings 4:1).

    Response: Daily sins, unless by added contumacy and contempt they become grave and subject to scandal, seem not in Scripture to be so punished; these are purged by daily and ordinary repentance. But those sins require extraordinary and open repentance. Nor yet secret grave sins, so long as they remain secret, as is seen in Matthew 18:15. Therefore, only grave and open sins, and those needing extraordinary and open means to bring the man unto repentance.

  2. Nor even in grave or most grave sins, unless there be added contumacy and long rebellion against all private and public admonitions. And that against the ancient Novatians and the recent Mennonites, who in such sins first excommunicate the man and then admonish him; for they will that he do penance without the Church, not within it, from the place1 Corinthians 5:1, where Paul premitteth no admonition but simply willeth the incestuous man to be excommunicated.

    3. Response: But this place alone is not to be regarded; others also must be compared. For in 2 Corinthians 2:6-7, 9, the Apostle willeth that after rebuke or epitimia by many, he be forgiven; therefore, admonition preceded when he was not yet excommunicated. The place of Christ is manifest (Matthew 18:17), and Titus 3:10.

XXXVII. The Limits of Excommunication

The force of ecclesiastical excommunication extendeth not unto corporal things, whether the taking away of bodily goods or of life.

Junius saith: Political communion is that which is exercised in matters and affairs pertaining unto civil and present life; but from this excommunication simply separateth no man. For men are not forbidden with their wives (1 Corinthians 7:12-13, etc.)—which is to be noted against the Anabaptists—nor parents with children, etc., after excommunication, to communicate politically, to dwell with them, and to perform due offices (for this is the law of nature, which cannot be taken away), provided they partake not in the same crime and by overmuch conversation contract contagion. Otherwise, outside such case of necessity, familiarity with the excommunicated is forbidden, lest their contumacy seem to be nourished (1 Corinthians 5:11), with this law, that we have them not as enemies but admonish them as brethren, that they may have regard unto themselves and the Church (2 Thessalonians 3:14-15).

Martyr saith: Now let us declare from what things he is excluded who is separated from the Church by excommunication. If it be expressed in one word, it is the fellowship of the faithful, among whom there is communion when commerce is not forbidden for the cause of religion. But it is meet that communion be distinguished: one is internal and toward God, unto whom we are joined by faith, hope, charity, and all virtues through our spirit, and also by the same works with all who believe in Christ. The other is external, whereby we are partakers both of the sacraments and of conversation with the members of the Church. From that former communion, excommunication doth not at all cast us out as the first and chief cause; but thence each falleth by his own sin when he acteth against faith, opposeth charity, and resisteth the other virtues. But from the latter, excommunication repelleth us, that we be not partakers of the sacraments and of the society of the faithful; and the latter altogether dependeth upon the former. For for no other cause is any man excommunicated but because he is declared alien from God and from the charity of neighbors by some grave, known, and manifest sin. Moreover, because Paul wrote, “Otherwise ye must needs go out of the world,” he hinteth that all fellowship is not wholly taken from the excommunicated; for in things without whose aid we could not live, it is lawful to communicate with them. For if perchance the magistrate were excommunicated, and meanwhile something occurreth which ought to be done and dealt with him, commerce with him is not to be refused, lest the commonwealth be disturbed. And the same is to be held if a father or husband be excommunicated; not for that cause are the wife or children exempt from his company, nor for his conversation are they to be excommunicated, unless they consent or partake in the same crime. Nor is a different rule to be set concerning buying merchandise from the excommunicated, if necessary for livelihood they cannot be had elsewhere. For if all evil men were to be avoided in purchases and civil contracts, it would be needful to go out of the world. Though I confess that, since today the churches are very large, we are not so pressed by this necessity. For what we cannot obtain from some, we easily obtain from others.

Walaeus saith: Question: It is asked whether under this pretext it be lawful for spouses to deny conjugal duties, or for parents to deny what is due from children, etc., as the Anabaptists do.

Response: But we deny this, for moral and natural bonds are not broken hereby, as is seen in the saying of Christ concerning Corban, the oath (Mark 7:11; 1 Corinthians 7:12), where Paul willeth that the faithful be not separated from the unfaithful spouse if she consent to dwell with him; and the matter is evident of itself, that ceremonial and ritual things ought to yield unto moral, as in David eating the shewbread, or the disciples of Christ rubbing ears of corn on the Sabbath.

Another Question: Whether by excommunication princes are divested of their kingdoms or dominions, and likewise whether peoples are released from the oath of fidelity which they have rendered unto them. We dispute not here whether the Pontiff justly assumeth unto himself the power of excommunicating any kings, concerning which we have treated afore, when we showed it false what the Papists claim, that they have either direct dominion over all kingdoms of the world, as the Canonists will, or indirect, as others will; but whether, it being supposed that some magistrate or king be justly excommunicated by his pastor or by the Church over which he presideth as king, he therefore falleth from his political power over his subjects. This we deny:

  1. The reason is that excommunication only separateth from ecclesiastical communion, not from moral or natural, as was shown before. But the dominion of magistrates over subjects is of the moral law, from the fifth commandment, repeated by express command (Romans 13:1): “Let every soul be subject unto the higher powers.” And1 Peter 2:13: “Submit yourselves to every ordinance of man for the Lord’s sake: whether it be to the king, as supreme; or unto governors, as unto them that are sent by him.”
  2. For the faithful can and ought to be subject unto unfaithful and heretical magistrates, as the places above show; therefore, also unto the excommunicated.
  3. For private persons lose not their own private goods by excommunication, nor particular honors; therefore, neither do kings or magistrates lose their hereditary and lawful kingdoms. Soto saith that excommunication is not the privation of any proper good which the transgressor of the law afore possessed, but the privation of common goods which he was to receive from the Church, as of spiritual communion and the reception of the sacraments.
  4. Then, the condition of Christian kings, with respect unto their kingdoms, would be worse than that of unfaithful kings, who cannot be excommunicated.
  5. The examples of Theodosius, Julian, Maximus the tyrant, who, being excommunicated, yet for that cause were not cast out of their empires; nor before Boniface VII was any such thing ever attempted.

Objection 1: The example of Saul (1 Samuel 15:23), who, being excommunicated by Samuel, lost the kingdom.

Response: But this pertaineth not hereto:

  1. For it was done by the sentence of God.
  2. For he still held the kingdom all his life.
  3. For Samuel never released the subjects from the oath, etc.

Objection 2: The example of Uzziah (2 Chronicles 26:20), who, being cast out of the temple by the priests, was also cast out from the administration of the kingdom.

Response: Not the priests, but the law of God constrained him to abstain from the administration of the kingdom, because lepers could not converse among men; yet he possessed the royal dignity all his life, though his son Jotham administered it for him. This is evidently proved, for Uzziah was made a leper in the twenty-seventh year of his age, but afterward is reckoned the thirty-seventh and thirty-eighth year of his reign.

Objection 3 & Response: The example of Athaliah (2 Kings 11:4), cast out by Jehoiada, also pertaineth not hereto, for Athaliah was a usurper of the kingdom, Joash the true heir; therefore, he did it not by excommunication but by arms, which any subject can and ought to do, to aid the lawful king according to his strength against the invader and tyrant of the kingdom.

Ames saith: The wonted censures of the Pontiffs, Pontificals, bishops, and their officials deserve themselves a grave censure; for they are profanations of the divine name, props of unjust domination, and snares for other men’s money, not spiritual remedies for such sins. Indulgences, commutations, and human transactions in those things for which Christ instituted the discipline of the Church are the merchandise of the great whore.

XXXVIII. The Duration and Release of Excommunication

Nor doth excommunication bind longer than for the impenitence of the sinner, who, when he repenteth, is loosed from that bond, which is not applied for his destruction but for his repentance and salvation.

Junius saith: But by this external excommunication, the presbytery doth not properly separate the impenitent from internal communion, but declareth him to be separated, so that as he is before God, so also he may be held before the Church (thus in the Old Testament, the priest did not infect the leper whom he judged with leprosy, but pronounced him infected). Hence, certain Scholastics rightly say: by excommunication, spiritual goods are not taken away, but are declared to be taken away; the Church doth not harm but showeth him harmed (Gabriel Biel and Bonaventure, In Sententias, Book 4, Distinction 18, Question 2). For ecclesiastical judgment is naught else but the promulgation on earth of the sentence decreed in heaven, whereof the word of God supplieth the thesis, but the matter itself confirmeth the hypothesis. Wherefore, external excommunication is not a brute thunderbolt, but in heaven also it is made and held ratified through the internal; and they who are lawfully cast out of the communion of the Church on earth are also decreed aliens from the internal grace of God, according to the promise of Christ: “Whatsoever ye shall bind on earth shall be bound in heaven” (Matthew 18:18). But this casting out is not absolute but conditional, namely, unless repentance intervene; which intervening, the excommunicated is to be received, lest, the hope of pardon being cut off, he be swallowed up with overmuch sorrow (2 Corinthians 2:7). Whence it followeth, according to the immutability of election, that by the external excommunication of the Church, the elect cease not to be members of Christ, though for a time they labor under atrophy and, as to the force and efficacy of the spirit, are not living members, much less fruitful. The end of this ecclesiastical discipline is twofold: common and singular. The common is the assertion of the glory of God, that:

  1. They who lead a shameful and scandalous life may not be numbered among the members of the Church with contumely and blasphemy of the divine name (1 Corinthians 5:1; Romans 2:24; Isaiah 52:5; Ezekiel 36:23).
  2. The impenitent may be rendered anapologetoi (without excuse).

The singular is the salvation of the Church, that:

  1. The contumacious, suffused with shame, may repent, and, being chastised, may learn not to sin (1 Corinthians 5:5; 2 Thessalonians 3:14; 1 Timothy 1:20; Jude 23), for affliction, as they say, giveth understanding.
  2. The good may not be corrupted by the examples and overmuch familiarity with the wicked (1 Corinthians 5:6), for, as Augustine saith (De Correctione et Gratia, Chapter 15), pastoral necessity requireth that dire contagions creep not through many, to separate from the sound sheep the diseased, to be healed perchance by that very separation by Him to whom nothing is impossible.
  3. Others may be kept in their duty and deterred from sins (1 Timothy 5:20).
  4. The sacraments and love-feasts may not be polluted, and the wrath of God kindled (1 Corinthians 10:21-22; Jude 12).

Ames saith: From the bond of excommunication, none impenitent ought to be loosed, nor ought it to be denied unto any penitent. But sufficient repentance is not if one say, “I repent, I will do so no more,” and otherwise showeth not true repentance; rather, such signs of earnest repentance ought to appear that the Church is bound to rest therein; otherwise, hypocrisy is fostered, and the Church and Christ Himself are deceived. Because it so effectually urgeth obedience toward Christ, therefore not without singular reason, a great part of the kingdom of Christ, as He visibly ruleth the Church, is placed by the best theologians in this discipline. And this very thing is the true cause why, in so few churches of the disciples of Christ, together with doctrine, it is soundly established and exercised, because even most of those who seem to know Christ and hope in Him refuse to receive the whole kingdom of Christ and to yield themselves wholly unto it.

XXXIX. The Adversaries of the Church

The adversaries of the Church are the unfaithful, heretics, and schismatics.

Spanheim saith: Concerning the nature and marks of the true Church, it hath been treated. Now it is to be treated concerning the false, which, with the appearance of the true, occupieth or bewildereth many, and is not the house of the living God but the workshop of Satan, not the pillar and ground of the truth but of a lie. The false Church is either the assembly of open enemies of the true Church or of covert ones, whereof the former are robbers, the latter actors; both turn Bethel into Bethaven, truth into a lie, and are employed by Satan to oppose and subvert the true Church. Concerning both kinds of the false Church, but briefly, it is to be treated. Thus, the former kind of the false Church is that which consisteth of open enemies of the true Church, and is the assembly of those who are averse from the true knowledge of the true God and of His Christ, such as may be reduced unto four classes: Gentiles, Jews, Samaritans, or Mohammedans. The latter kind of the Church is that which consisteth of covert enemies of the true Church, and is the assembly of those who, feigning the name of the true Christian Church, are averse from the saving knowledge of the true God and of His Christ, of whom well-nigh innumerable classes may be formed, and they have their name either from doctors, or from dogmas, or from the manner of life. From doctors, the Arians, Samosatenians, Marcionites, Sabellians, Pelagians, and others have drawn their name; from dogmas, the Chiliasts, Anthropomorphites, Ophites, Cathari, Monothelites, and others; from the manner of life, as the Apostolics, Euchetae, Encratites, and others. The number of seducers, who may be called the patriarchs of heresies, is great, but of the seduced almost without number. They may be distinguished by the object: for either they foster false and perilous opinions concerning the person of Christ, or His office, or His benefits, or the manner of applying them, or the duty of man, or many at once. Concerning which, see Augustine, Epiphanius, Isidore, Philastrius, and others, who have woven long catalogues of such. In our age, passing over here the consideration both of the Greek Church in the East and of some churches of the West, which are indeed erroneous but recede less from purity, and of the fanatical assemblies, of which divers classes in divers kingdoms and provinces of Europe, and of which swarms the most flourishing or especially the neighboring kingdom in recent years hath both excluded and condemned, three kinds of the false Church which chiefly prevail in our age are to be considered:

  1. The Church of the Antitrinitarians.
  2. The Church of the Anabaptists.
  3. The Church of the Papists.

Polanus saith: Three things conjoined make a heretical man: error, conviction, and contumacy. But not every error maketh a heretic, as that which toucheth only some lesser dogma, not so simply and properly necessary unto faith; for such error is of a wretched man erring from the way in the way, yet retaining the head, and thus falling unto his Lord and to be raised by his Lord, for God can establish him, as the Apostle Paul speaketh (Romans 14:4). Wherefore, neither doth the truth call a man overtaken by such error a heretic and antichrist, nor ought charity, nor doth the authority of the Lord command it. But that error maketh a heretic which is contrary unto some chief dogma of the Christian faith or article of faith, or unto many, and so striketh against the foundation of Christian doctrine. For heresy is properly in matters of faith. Then, not every one who erreth in faith is a heretic, for he may err from simplicity and ignorance in faith. Nor is every one who so erreth, yet is ready to hear one teaching better and truer things and to yield unto the truth, nor every one who is once or twice convicted of error, a heretic; but whosoever, in error demonstrated and convicted by the authority of the word of God, is contumacious and persisteth therein. Of heretics, some are erring only, others inducing others into error, or at least attempting so. The erring either fall privately unto God and themselves, or are an offense unto others by the public profession and demonstration of their error. But the seducing either attempt to lead partly into error or persuade full apostasy. Therefore, not all erring, but they who depart from the foundation and persist in demonstrated error, are pertinaciously made aliens from the Church of God. Heretical churches likewise err, some more grievously and dangerously than others: some in one head of Christian doctrine, some in many; and again, some in a principal head, some in a less principal. But if they sink from heresy into apostasy, then they wholly cease to be churches of Christ. This cometh to pass where Christ, the head of the Church, the Savior and Mediator, is not acknowledged; where that mediation whereby Christ joineth the Church, as the neck joineth the body unto the head, is cut off, and consequently Christ hath publicly pronounced divorce unto those churches which have openly flown into the marriage and bed of another, and invoke not God any more through Christ, nor seek eternal salvation any more through Christ. An example is in the Asiatic churches, which everywhere from the Nestorian heresy descended unto Mohammedan impiety and, leaving Christ, passed into the bed of Mohammed.

Maccovius saith: Schism is a secession in the business of religion, either rash or unjust, whether it be made or continued. In Holy Scripture, it is called secession (1 John 2:19). It doubtless denoteth those who had seceded from the Church, yet had professed themselves members thereof. Nor yet are they designated who have lapsed into heathenism or Judaism, for they indeed have committed a graver crime than can be called schism. But neither is every secession in the business of religion schism; for Scripture maketh mention of a twofold secession. For there is a certain secession in good, laudable and approved, see Isaiah 52:11, which the Apostle repeated and applied unto his purpose (2 Corinthians 6:17-18). In Revelation, this voice is said to have been heard from heaven: “Come out of her, my people, that ye be not partakers of her sins.” But such secession is not schism; therefore, schism is a secession either rash or unjust. For there is some schism which none can call wholly wicked and unjust, yet rash, because it hath a slight cause; which schism, if pertinacity be added (and it will be added if the lightness of the cause be shown), will be truly and kat’ exochen schism. That the matter may be more fully understood, it is to be held that, as of every schism, so of rash schism, the knowledge is either from the prior or from the posterior. From the prior, for none is driven to make a schism but by love of himself or of his own. Whence also it cometh that, a schism being rashly made, hatred interveneth. Yea, truly, there is no schism rashly where there is place for charity. For, as the Apostle saith (1 Corinthians 13), charity is not suspicious, charity is not contentious. Moreover, schism is rashly made either by the authors or by those who follow the author. And the authors indeed rashly make schism when they have had not a grave but a light occasion thereof. Also, the rashness of secession is detected from the posterior, if its occasion be light; but it will be light unless either a grave and intolerable persecution hath befallen, or that assembly from which the secession is made laboreth under heresy, or indeed is given unto idolatry. For if the persecution be tolerable, yet secession be made, that secession will not indeed be unjust, but yet it will have been rash and schism. Thirdly, secession is rashly made, as if there be some error in the assembly from which secession is made, which is not the same as heresy or superstition, a superstitious rite which is not the same as idolatry. For if the error be tolerable, secession ought not to be made, because unless the disease be lethal and contagious, the sick is not to be forsaken, yea, not even then unless very grievously. Fourthly, secession is also rashly made when it is for corruptions of morals, whereto that of Christ pertaineth: “They sit in Moses’ seat: all therefore whatsoever they bid you observe, that observe and do” (Matthew 23:2-3). The reason hereof is that wherever purity of doctrine flourisheth, it is necessary that God have a Church in that assembly, though oft almost overwhelmed by the multitude of scandals. And so, they who make secession from such an assembly doubtless secede from thence where God gathereth the Church. Unjust secession is that which is made when no persecution hath arisen, no heresy or error rageth in the Church, no superstition or idolatry obtaineth, when there are no scandals in the Church or almost none. It was said last in the definition of schism, secession either made or continued. For very oft, the authors and chiefs of schism being taken away, the secession is continued in their posterity. But this is to be noted, that it oft happeneth that a Church which hath schismatic pastors is not forthwith itself schismatic. For those pastors are schismatic who study to stir up envy or hatred against their brethren, when yet the flock is not at all schismatic, for it is ignorant of what is done. Whereof we have an example in Scripture (Philippians 1:15-18), where Paul complaineth that there are many who preach the Gospel through contention and envy, “that they may add affliction to my bonds,” he saith. Moreover, schism is distinguished in divers ways: either from the occasion, as when the occasion is light or none; or from the manner, as if we say that schism is one thing, as they speak in the schools, negative, another positive. Negative schism is that which goeth not out into any assembly and religious society, but is simply secession and withdrawal, when a Church is not instituted by the schism made. Positive schism is when a Church is instituted, that is, when some association useth ecclesiastical laws and the word of God and the administration of the sacraments separately, which, a certain form being ended, is said from Scripture to build an altar against an altar. But this schism is called kat’ exochen schism. The reason why it is so called is that very oft negative secession is legitimate, yet it will not be legitimate if it be positive; that is, it cometh to pass that it is lawful rightly and godly to secede from some assembly, yet it is not straightway lawful to institute a new assembly.
